McCarrey c, Joshua Oon Soo Goh a,d,e,f,g, * a Graduate Institute of Brain and Mind Sciences, College of Medicine, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan b Taiwan International Graduate Program in Interdisciplinary Neuroscience, National Taiwan University and Academia Sinica, Taipei, Taiwan c Department of Psychology, Idaho State University, Pocatello, ID, USA d Department of Psychology, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan e Neurobiology and Cognitive Science Center, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan f Center for Artiﬁcial Intelligence and Advanced Robotics, National Taiwan University, Taipei, Taiwan g Laboratory of Behavioral Neuroscience, Intramural Research Program, National Institute on Aging, Baltimore, MD, USA  a r t i c l e i n f o  a b s t r a c t  Article history: Received 26 October 2017 Received in revised form 12 May 2018 Accepted 14 May 2018 Available online 21 May 2018  Keywords: Aging Brain function Value-based decision-making fMRI  Appropriate neural representation of value and application of decision strategies are necessary to make optimal investment choices in real life. Normative human aging alters neural selectivity and control processing in brain regions implicated in value-based decision processing including striatal, medial temporal, and frontal areas. However, the speciﬁc neural mechanisms of how these age-related functional brain changes modulate value processing in older adults remain unclear. Here, young and older adults performed a lottery-choice functional magnetic resonance imaging experiment in which probabilities of winning different magnitudes of points constituted expected values of stakes. Increasing probability of winning modulated striatal responses in young adults, but modulated medial temporal and ventromedial prefrontal areas instead in older adults. Older adults additionally engaged higher responses in dorso-medio-lateral prefrontal cortices to more unfavorable stakes. Such extrastriatal involvement mediated age-related increase in risk-taking decisions. Furthermore, lower resting-state functional connectivity between lateral prefrontal and striatal areas also predicted lottery-choice task risk-taking that was mediated by higher functional connectivity between prefrontal and medial temporal areas during the task, with this mediation relationship being stronger in older than younger adults. Overall, we report evidence of a systemic neural mechanistic change in processing of probability in mixed-lottery values with age that increases risk-taking of unfavorable stakes in older adults. Moreover, individual differences in age-related effects on baseline frontostriatal communication may be a central determinant of such subsequent age differences in value-based decision neural processing and resulting behaviors. Ó 2018 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.  1. Introduction  Real life investments typically entail an expected gain proportional to the invested resource but also a possible loss, depending on outcomes. For instance, one spends money to buy an apple expecting to eat a juicy fruit but there is always a probability that there is a worm in the apple and the money spent is wasted. To maximize investments and minimize losses during such mixed lottery situations, neural networks in the human brain must be able  * Corresponding author at: Graduate Institute of Brain and Mind Sciences, College of Medicine, National Taiwan University, No. 1 Ren-Ai Rd. Section 1, RM 1554, Zhongzheng District, Taipei, Taiwan 10051. Tel: þ886 2 2312 3456 88022; fax: þ886 2 2322 4814.  E-mail address: joshuagoh@ntu.edu.tw (J.O.S. Goh).  0197-4580/$ e see front matter Ó 2018 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neurobiolaging.2018.05.019  to represent information about stimuli value, such as the expected value (EV) of investments, as accurately as possible with respect to physical outcomes. Neural processing of mixed lotteries might also engage relevant strategies or beliefs where necessary or effective (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979), such as noting past negative experiences at a particular grocery store, or prioritizing physical or mental health over money, or using only partial information to simplify decisions. Aging changes human brain functions such that neural representations of different stimuli are less distinctive (Goh et al., 2010; Park et al., 2004; Yassa et al., 2011) and the ﬂexible engagement of goal-directed control and strategic processing is diminished (Ardiale and Lemaire, 2012; Hakun et al., 2015; Harris and Wolbers, 2014; Konishi et al., 2013). Older adults also display distinct decision behaviors compared with young adults that, across different experimental contexts, reﬂect more variable decision  186  Y.-S. Su et al. / Neurobiology of Aging 69 (2018) 185e198  criteria, such as not always choosing options with higher EVs, and more reactive decision strategies, such as being more sensitive to recent outcomes (Pachur et al., 2017; Rutledge et al., 2016; Tymula et al., 2013; Worthy et al., 2016). These brain and behavioral differences between young and older adults motivate the need to determine the mechanistic links between changes in human neural processing of value and decision-making behavior as a person ages, particularly in light of the aging world demographic (Vaupel, 2010). Here, we reconcile how age effects on neural operations that selectively process information and apply goal-directed strategies impact assessment of EV in a risky lottery choice task (LCT).  In the LCT (Goh et al., 2016), which tests mixed lottery decisions, different probabilities (P) of winning (and simultaneously, losing; 1eP) are combined with different magnitudes (M) of points such that EV ¼ PM þ (1eP)(␀M) for any given trial (Fig. 1A). Stakes and outcomes are independent across trials so that the optimal approach is to decide to accept or reject the given stakes based solely on the objective information about EV provided in each trial. Moreover, because for any given magnitude of points, the probability of winning also determines the probability of losing the points, risk-neutral agents should have an acceptance decision threshold (DT) or certainty equivalence set at EV ¼ 0 (or p ¼ 50%) (Dohmen et al., 2011). DTs greater or less than EV ¼ 0 indicate riskaverse or risk-taking preferences, respectively.  Performance in this task might, in principle, rely on neural representations of EV (or even more simply, P) in ventral striatum (VS) that shows sensitivity to different levels of expected rewards or losses (Berns et al., 2001; Knutson et al., 2001; Preuschoff et al.,  2006; Schultz, 2000; Tom et al., 2007). Differential sensitivity to value underlies the role of VS in gating and selecting adaptive motor responses to obtain rewards or avoid losses (Nicola, 2007). However, the main neurotransmitter that operates in this region, dopamine, has reduced efﬁcacy with age (Dreher et al., 2008; Erixon-Lindroth et al., 2005; Kaasinen et al., 2000; Wong et al., 1997). Neurocomputational theory projects that reduced dopaminergic efﬁcacy results in lower signal-to-noise ratio during information processing that underlies less distinctive neuronal responses (or lower neural sensitivity) to different stimuli in target brain areas (Bäckman et al., 2010; Li and Sikström, 2002). In older adults then, we expect less neural sensitivity to valuative information in VS. This increases the likelihood that decisions will be less inﬂuenced by objective EV information and more inﬂuenced by more subjective processes in other brain regions that bias decision criteria.  Experiments have shown dissociable age-related biases in loss processing compared with gains (Mather et al., 2012; Pachur et al., 2017; Samanez-Larkin et al., 2007, 2010). This is consistent with socioemotional selectivity theory (Carstensen, 2006; Carstensen et al., 1999; Mather and Carstensen, 2005) that posits a shift in life goals toward senescence such that maintenance of well-being or positive affect has greater inﬂuence on older than younger adult decision-making. Two extensions are made in relation to EV processing. First, there should be enhanced affective reactions to prospects in general in older compared with younger adults, who should be more apathetic. Speciﬁcally, neural responses that track the desirability of EVs should be more evident in older than young adults in brain areas involved in affective processing. In our whole-brain  Fig. 1. (A) Sample trial from the LCT showing the percentage probability of winning (or losing) a given magnitude of points during the choice phase. If participants decide to accept the given stake, the outcome points are given (outcome top number; example depicts a winning trial outcome) with the accumulated points (outcome bottom number) updated accordingly. If the participants decide to reject the stake, the missed outcome is given in parentheses with no change in accumulated points. (B, C) Violin plots depicting probability density distributions of young and older adult DT EVs and adjusted DTs ð to win (or lose) and points magnitudes (see Supplementary Table S2) for young and older adults. * denote p < 0.05 with Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons. Error bar indicates SEM. Abbreviations: DT, decision threshold; EV, expected value; ISI, interstimulus interval; LCT, lottery choice task.  p Þ. White circles are individual data points. (D) Acceptance rates across the different levels of probability ﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃ DT  Y.-S. Su et al. / Neurobiology of Aging 69 (2018) 185e198  187  analysis, we focus on affective responses in the amygdala and anterior medial temporal lobe (MTL) and ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC) as these have previously been implicated during LCT processing (Goh et al., 2016) and other value-related experiments (Berns et al., 2001; Knutson et al., 2003; Phelps, 2004; Phelps et al., 2014). Second, older adults should engage greater down-regulation processing in response to situations that induce negative affect because positive affective reactions should not require regulation. As such, dorsomedial and dorsolateral frontal (DMPFC and DLPFC) engagement to down-regulate negative affect associated with unfavorable EVs should be more enhanced in older than younger adults (Mather and Knight, 2005). Overall, we expect that neural engagement in young and older adults during mixed lotteries should shift from an emphasis on veridical EV responses in the VS to more affective-like and regulatory responses in MTL and frontal regions. Given our previous ﬁnding of an overall risk-taking preference in older adults as a group during the LCT (Goh et al., 2016), we also expect here that greater expression of such affective-like neural responses should be associated with greater propensity to accept lossdominant mixed lotteries in the older age group. Speciﬁcally, we expected age differences in risk-taking behavior to be mediated by age differences in VS, MTL, and frontal neural responses to EV during choice processing in value-based decisions.  functional  Finally, if indeed there is a systemic alteration of brain regions involved in valuative processing with age, a more network approach to evaluate how age modulates the associations between brain inter-regional connectivity and risk-taking behavior might provide further complementary support for the aforementioned considerations based on regional neural responses. Evidence shows that lower white matter structural connectivity between frontal and striatal areas is an important determinant of the ability of older adults to process probabilistic reward (SamanezLarkin et al., 2012). In addition, antecedent reduction in frontal white matter tissue integrity is a hallmark of normative age-related structural brain changes that have been associated with cognitive decline, particularly in tests of executive function (Borghesani et al., 2013; Fjell et al., 2017; Gazes et al., 2016; Head et al., 2004; Hedden et al., 2016; Kennedy and Raz, 2009; Madden et al., 2017, 2009; Sullivan et al., 2010a,b). At least one study has also shown links between age differences in white matter structural connectivity, functional connectivity, and cognitive performance (Davis et al., 2012), albeit focusing on callosal connections between prefrontal homologs. Thus, age-related changes in frontal white matter tissue integrity suggests that age differences in baseline frontostriatal functional communication (as indicated by resting-state functional connectivity) should play a central role in older adult value-based decision neural processing and behavior.  We reasoned that neural functional communication during LCT processing (or LCT-related functional connectivity) might reﬂect a mediatory response to a primary effect of frontostriatal baseline resting-state functional connectivity on LCT risk-taking behavior. Speciﬁcally, disruption of frontostriatal baseline functional connectivity with age should drive altered functional communication in other neural networks engaged during decision processing tasks in older relative to younger adults that then inﬂuences older adult task-related decision behavior. In this light, we also examined functional connectivity between the frontal, striatal, and medial temporal areas during LCT performance and during resting-state in the same young and older individuals. We expected that if frontostriatal baseline connectivity is an important determinant of older adult value-based decision processing, then LCT-related functional connectivity between these brain regions should mediate between frontostriatal resting-state functional connectivity and LCT decision behavior, and that this mediation should be moderated by age.  2. Materials and methods  2.1. Participants  A total of 44 younger and 54 older adults volunteered for this study. Exclusion criteria were presence or history of neurological or psychiatric disorder, artiﬁcial implants, or other counterindications for MRI scanning. All participants underwent the MRI session followed by a neuropsychological test session on a separate day within 1 month. All participants gave written informed consent on the day of the MRI session for this study, which was approved by National Taiwan University Hospital Research Ethics Committee. From all volunteers, we excluded 2 younger and 6 older adults because of excessive head motion (>3.4375 mm translation or >3 rotation; on the basis of the size of 1 voxel) during functional scanning, 1 younger and 4 older adults because of having null responses for more than 15 trials in the LCT (the total number of trials in 1 condition), 3 older adults who showed equal acceptance of all choice conditions or greater acceptance of loss-dominant than gain-dominant conditions (indicating failure to understand the task), and 1 younger and 1 older adult who dropped out of neuropsychological testing (precluding assessment of cognitive status). The remaining participants entered into the analysis were 40 younger (mean age: 23.3 years; SD: 1.97 years; age range: 20.2e28.5 years; 14/26 males/females) and 40 older adults (mean age: 67.9 years; SD: 4.93 years; age range: 59.2e77.7 years; 12/28 males/females) (Supplementary Table S1). Mini-Mental State Exam scores for these participants were greater than 26 except for 1 older adult who scored 25, and 1 who scored 24, which were still within the normal range based on local age-adjusted norms (Sun et al., 2014). Participants were remunerated for their time in the study. One older participant did not contribute restingstate functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data due to technical failure while scanning.  2.2.  fMRI LCT stimuli, procedures, and behavioral analyses  The LCT task has been described in detail in Goh et al. (2016) involving a larger sample study of older individual differences. In this present LCT fMRI experiment, we adopted an expanded version to yield more robust estimates of neural response differences between young and older adults. Brieﬂy here, each trial in the LCT was divided into choice and outcome phases (Fig. 1A). The choice phase presented text depicting the win/lose probability and points magnitude. While probabilities and magnitudes varied continuously, choice conditions were treated as discretized ranges to facilitate counterbalancing during stimuli generation, presentation ordering, and also speciﬁc aspects of data analysis below. Supplementary Table S2 details the means and ranges of probabilities, magnitudes, and resulting EVs of each condition. There were 5 levels of win probability (low-low, LL*; middle-low, ML*; middle-middle, MM*; middle-high, MH*; high-high, HH*) and 3 levels of magnitude (low, *L; middle, *M; high, *H) comprising the 15 choice conditions (LLL, LLM, LLH, MLL, MLM MLH, MML, MMM, MMH, MHL, MHM, MHH, HHL, HHM, HHH). Note, participants were agnostic to these discrete choice conditions and stimuli probabilities and magnitudes were continuously distributed from their perspective.  Choice text stimuli remained on the screen for 4 seconds, within which subjects decided to accept or reject the stakes with assigned button presses in the right hand. The choice phase was followed by a ﬁxation (with interstimulus interval [ISI] ranging from 1 to 5 seconds; jittered across trials) after which the outcome phase was presented for 2 seconds. Note that each trial presents a mixed lottery so that the magnitude at stake to be gained is also the same magnitude at stake to be lost. Outcomes were stochastically predetermined based on actual stakes of each trial with the limitation  188  Y.-S. Su et al. / Neurobiology of Aging 69 (2018) 185e198  that no condition could have only winning or only losing predetermined outcomes across all trials of that condition. If participants accepted the stakes, depending on the predetermined outcome, the outcome phase feedback would be either a gain or a loss with increased or decreased accumulated points, respectively. If participants rejected the stakes, outcomes would also be presented within parenthesis with no change in the accumulated points. Null responses also resulted in no change in points but with a reminder message to respond. Participants were given the goal to maximize their total accumulated points across 225 LCT trials. A ﬁxation (ISI ranging from 1 to 5 seconds; jittered across trials) then followed outcome phases before the beginning of the next trial. No combinations of probability and magnitude were repeated throughout the experiment.  Participants underwent a familiarization practice version of the LCT before MRI scanning. fMRI experimental stimuli were presented using E-Prime software version 2.0 (Psychology Software Tools, Sharpsburg, PA, USA) back-projected onto a screen at the front of the scanner that participants viewed using a mirror mounted on the head coil. There were a total of 5 runs of fMRI scanning each consisting of 45 trials (3 trials per choice condition in each run). Trial conditions were presented in pseudorandom order such that there were no more than 2 consecutive trials with the same choice condition.  Analyses of behavioral responses were conducted using R version 3.3.1 (www.r-project.org). To obtain an individual index of risk preferences, logistic regression was applied on each participant’s binary accept/reject responses using trialwise EV as the independent variable ½log ðResponseÞ ¼ b0 þ b1EV þ ε to yield DTs ½␀ðb0=b1Þ for each individual. DT is thus the estimated EV at which a participant’s acceptance rate (AR ¼ Naccepted trials/Nresponded trials) was at chance (0.5) (Supplementary Fig. S1) (Dohmen et al., 2011). ARs for each participant were also evaluated for the different discretized levels of probability of winning and magnitude comprising the 15 choice conditions. ARs for all choice conditions were submitted as the dependent variable in a 3-way repeated measures mixed-effects analysis of variance (ANOVA) with probability and magnitude as within-subject independent variables and age as a between-subjects independent variable. To interrogate simple effects from the omnibus ANOVAs, post hoc comparisons were conducted using the “emmeans” package version 1.1 in R with Satterthwaite estimation of degrees of freedom. Speciﬁcally, pairwise comparisons of mean ARs between young and older adults for each choice condition were further conducted to evaluate signiﬁcant interactions associated with age based on the ANOVA with signiﬁcance thresholded at p < 0.05 with Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons. Similarly, response times (RTs) across the 15 choice conditions were also submitted to a 3-way ANOVA with post hoc evaluation of simple effects using the emmeans package in R.  2.3. Brain imaging acquisition protocol  Brain imaging was performed using a 32-channel head coil with a 3T Skyra System (Siemens Medical Solutions, Erlangen, Germany) located at National Cheng-Chi University, Taipei, Taiwan. For each participant, functional images were acquired using an echo-planar pulse sequence with TR ¼ 2000 ms, TE ¼ 24 ms, FA ¼ 90, 38 axial slices, 64  64 matrix, and 3.4375  3.4375  4 mm voxel resolution. Slices were aligned in parallel to the anterior-posterior commissural plane and positioned for whole-brain coverage. Two hundred eighteen volumes were acquired in each of the 5 functional experimental task runs and 180 volumes were acquired for 1 run of a resting-state fMRI experiment (rs-fMRI; eyes open focusing on a ﬁxation). A coplanar individual gradient ﬁeld map with short TE ¼ 4.92 ms, long TE ¼ 7.38 ms, and TR ¼ 500 ms, was acquired for  distortion correction and better spatial registration of the functional images. A coplanar T2-weighted structural image with TR ¼ 7480 ms, TE ¼ 102 ms, FA ¼ 150, 38 axial slices, 256  256 matrix, and 1  1  4 mm voxel resolution was also acquired for coregistration of functional to anatomical images. A high-resolution T1weighted magnetization prepared rapid acquisition gradient echo sequence with TR ¼ 2000 ms, TE ¼ 2.98 ms, FA ¼ 9, 192 sagittal slices, 256  256 matrix, and 1  1  1 mm voxel resolution, was acquired for normalization to template space.  2.4. LCT fMRI data preprocessing and analysis  Preprocessing and analyses of brain imaging data were conducted using SPM12 revision 6906 (Statistical Parametric Mapping, Wellcome Trust Centre for Neuroimaging, UK). We created a studyspeciﬁc template to minimize biasing of effects due to age differences in brain structure. The high-resolution T1-weighted images for each participant were segmented and submitted to the Diffeomorphic Anatomical Registration Through Exponentiated Linear Algebra procedure (Ashburner, 2007). This resulted in individual deformation ﬁeld maps that were subsequently applied to the functional data during the normalization step. For the functional images for each participant, we performed slice-time correction followed by head motion correction with unwarping based on the gradient ﬁeld map. Corrected functional images were then coregistered to the T2 then T1 structural images, and spatially normalized to the study-speciﬁc template with resampling at 3  3  3 mm voxels. Normalized functional images were then afﬁnetransformed to standard Montreal Neurological Institute space and smoothed with a 3D 8 mm full width at half maximum Gaussian kernel.  Our main whole-brain analysis of the functional imaging data applied an exploratory approach to identify brain regions in which there were any age-related differences in neural responses to the different probability and magnitude conditions. Note that in the LCT experimental design, where each trial had a choice and an outcome phase, these phases were interleaved by jittered ISIs so that ﬁrstlevel general linear models (GLMs) of voxel blood oxygen leveledependent signal timecourses separately modeled choice and outcome responses for each trial, albeit within the same model. Thus, in this main whole-brain analysis, the ﬁrst-level GLM included 18 primary regressors based on the onsets of the 15 discrete choice phase conditions (5 levels of probability  3 levels of magnitude; Supplementary Table S2) and 3 outcome phase conditions (gain, loss, reject; see aforementioned Behavioral Methods), convolved with the canonical hemodynamic response function (HRF). Temporal derivatives of the aforementioned regressors to account for age-related delay of blood oxygen leveledependent signals, null response choice and outcome phases (if present; onsets convolved with HRF), and 6 motion parameters were additionally used as covariates shown in Supplementary Methods). At the group-level, ﬁrst-level wholebrain voxelwise neural response estimates for the 15 choice conditions of each individual were submitted to a whole-brain voxelwise 3-way repeated-measures ANOVA with probability and magnitude as within-subject independent variables and age as a between-subjects independent variable. We focused on age  probability, age  magnitude, and age  probability  magnitude interactions to identify voxels across the whole brain in which any responses to probability or magnitude were signiﬁcantly modulated by age during the choice phase. Because our focus in this study was on choice-related neural processes, outcome responses are not presently evaluated further.  (model equation is  We also conducted a second supplementary whole-brain analysis using model-based fMRI analysis that evaluated neural  Y.-S. Su et al. / Neurobiology of Aging 69 (2018) 185e198  189  responses to probability and magnitude as continuous variables. Studies have shown that responses to probability show linear effects reﬂecting value processing as well as quadratic trends reﬂecting more uncertainty (Knutson et al., 2005; Preuschoff et al., 2006; Tobler et al., 2007). Thus, we applied this more speciﬁc model-based fMRI approach as a means to corroborate resulting age differences in whole-brain activity patterns from the general exploratory approach aforementioned, and to obtain voxelwise summary coefﬁcient measures of neural sensitivity to probability and magnitude for regions-of-interest (ROI) analyses below. In addition, this supplementary analysis further qualiﬁed whether neural responses in brain regions showing age-related differences in the main exploratory analysis were driven by linear probability or magnitude effects reﬂecting value processing or quadratic effects reﬂecting more uncertainty. A P2 regressor was included to account for the contribution of neural processing related to uncertainty, which should peak when p ¼ 0.5. As aforementioned, choice and outcome phase responses were assigned separate regressors within the same model. Different from the aforementioned model, the ﬁrst-level GLM for this supplementary approach included 9 primary regressors that included the onsets of all choice phases as 1 regressor convolved with the HRF, 5 regressors that modulated the choice phase regressor by trialwise probabilities in a linear (P) and quadratic (P2) manner, magnitudes (M), and their interactions (P  M, P2  M), and as in the main approach previously mentioned, 3 regressors for outcome phase conditions (gain, loss, reject) also convolved with the HRF. Temporal derivatives of the aforementioned regressors, null response trials (if present; convolved with HRF), and 6 motion parameters were included as covariates (see Supplementary Methods). Regressors that modulated the choice phase regressor were nonorthogonal. In sum, this model-based ﬁrst-level GLM yielded whole-brain coefﬁcient images reﬂecting each individual’s voxelwise neural sensitivity to trialwise changes in P, P2, M, and their interaction P  M, P2  M during the choice phase. At the group-level supplementary analysis, these ﬁrst-level whole-brain coefﬁcient images were submitted to one sample ttest to identify voxels showing signiﬁcant neural sensitivity to the respective choice phase parameters across the whole brain in young and older adult age groups.  Signiﬁcance thresholds for all whole-brain analyses were set at p < 0.001 (uncorrected) with cluster size >15 for cortical regions and p < 0.005 with cluster size >20 for subcortical regions. Similar separate criteria for cortical and subcortical regions was used in our previous publication using this same LCT task (Goh et al., 2016) and was a means to adapt to effect sizes in the smaller volumes of subcortical tissue. Both criteria fulﬁlled a whole-brain clusterwise false discovery rate (FDR) of p < 0.05 based on Monte-Carlo simulation with 10,000 iterations (https://www2.bc.edu/sd-slotnick/ scripts.htm; Slotnick, 2017; Slotnick et al., 2003).  2.5. ROI analysis  ROIs were deﬁned as 8 mm spheres around peak contrast voxels showing signiﬁcant interaction effects of age  probability and age  probability  magnitude from the main exploratory wholebrain analysis approach (age  magnitude did not yield signiﬁcant voxels, see results in the following). Neural functional response estimates for the 15 discrete choice conditions from the main whole-brain analysis were then extracted from ROIs for each individual participant. Response estimates were submitted as the dependent variable in mixed-effects linear regression analyses using R running the “lme4” package version 1.1e12 and ‘lmerTest’ package version 2.0e32. Independent variables in the mixedeffects linear model included probability (Prob; 5 levels), magnitude (Mag; 3 levels), age (2 levels; coded young ¼ 1, old ¼ ␀1), the  interactions between these prior variables (4 in total), and sex as ﬁxed effects, and the intercepts for each subject as well as for probability and magnitude nested in each subject as random effects. Satterthwaite approximations were used to obtain denominator degrees of freedom for hypothesis testing of model coefﬁcients. Polynomial contrasts of the model coefﬁcients were speciﬁed and evaluated to interrogate the discrete linear effect of probability (Problinear), and the quadratic effect of probability (Probquadratic) and their interactions with magnitude separately for young and older adults as well as comparing between age groups. Effects of Mag and age differences in Mag responses were not evaluated in ROIs as the whole-brain age  magnitude contrast did not yield signiﬁcant voxels, see results in the following. Individual neural sensitivity coefﬁcients for continuous trialwise changes in P from the supplementary whole-brain model-based approach were also extracted from ROIs and used in correlation analyses and the analysis of their role in mediating the effect of age on DT.  For ROIs that presented signiﬁcant correlations between neural sensitivity to probability (P) or magnitude (M) with DT, we further assessed their joint mediatory contribution in the effect of age on DT. Mediation analyses were conducted using the “lavaan” package version 0.5-23.1097 under the R environment. The mediation model assessed the effect of age (young vs. old; 1 vs. ␀1, respectively) on DT via neural sensitivity to P (based on the model-based fMRI analysis) in ROIs as multiple mediators (Mj), with the causal events formulated in the following equations. DT ¼ iDT þ cAge þ εDT Mj ¼ iMj þ ajAge þ εMj Age þ X DT ¼ iDT þ c  bjMj þ εDT  0  In the aforementioned equations, i denote the respective model intercepts, c and c0 denote coefﬁcients for the effect of age on DT before and after accounting for the contribution of multiple mediators, respectively, a is the coefﬁcient for the effect of age on the jth mediator, b is the coefﬁcient for the jth mediator’s effect on DT, and ε denotes the respective model residual. Inference regarding the mediations is then evaluated by signiﬁcance testing of the indirect effects aj  bj (Hayes, 2015; Hayes and Rockwood, 2017). Note, although DT is indicated in the aforementioned equations, all analyses of DT with respect to brain responses were based on square rooteadjusted values (see results in the following).  2.6. Functional connectivity preprocessing and analysis  To assess functional connectivity, brain imaging data from the LCT experiment and rs-fMRI scans were ﬁrst adjusted for slice timing, head motion, ﬁeld distortion, and coregistered to T1-weighted images as with the aforementioned preprocessing procedures. Spatial normalization and smoothing were not conducted for functional connectivity analysis. Preprocessed images were then ﬁltered to remove linear signal drifts and frequencies higher than 0.08 Hz and lower than 0.009 Hz from voxel timecourses. Finally, voxelwise regression was used to remove the effects of 6 dimensions of head motion, the mean signal within white matter, and mean signal within cerebrospinal ﬂuid, and for the LCTexperiment, the task contributions of the 15 choice and 3 feedback conditions. The resulting residual timecourses for each individual participant’s processed functional data were retained to assess functional connectivity between ROIs. ROIs from the aforementioned main whole-brain approach were deformed to each individual participant’s native space using the inverse individual ﬂow ﬁelds generated from the Diffeomorphic  190  Y.-S. Su et al. / Neurobiology of Aging 69 (2018) 185e198  Anatomical Registration Through Exponentiated Linear Algebra procedure. For each participant, mean residual timecourses from each ROI were cross-correlated to obtain inter-ROI Pearson correlation coefﬁcients. Correlation coefﬁcients were subjected to Fisher transformation to yield z-scores for subsequent analyses. Moderated mediation models were constructed to assess the modulatory inﬂuence of age (young vs. old; 1 vs. ␀1, respectively) on the mediatory role of LCT functional connectivity between ROIs (Mj) in the effect of resting-state functional connectivity (RSFC) between ROIs on DT (adjusted), which is formulated in the following equations. Results  3.1. Higher risk-taking in older than younger adults in lottery choice decisions  Older adults showed lower DTs than younger adults (old: DT (SD) ¼ ␀14.9 (22.9); young: DT (SD) ¼ ␀2.56 (7.20); t78 ¼ 3.24, p ¼ 0.002, Fig. 1B) indicating more risk-taking behavior in the former. p Square root adjustment of absolute DT to account for the skewed ﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃ distribution yielded the same statistical DT (SD) ¼ ␀2.66 (2.99); young: (SD) ¼ ␀0.98 (1.88); t78 ¼ 3.01, p ¼ 0.003, Fig. 1C) and this adjusted DT is used for subsequent correlations against neural responses. Removing the 4 older individuals with the lowest DTs did not change the overall results (Supplementary Results) so that these were considered within representative performance range (see also Goh et al., 2016).  p ﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃ DT  result  (old:  Analysis of AR across the 15 choice conditions further revealed that age differences were present from middle to lower probability conditions (Fig. 1D). Speciﬁcally, a repeated measures ANOVA yielded signiﬁcant interaction effects between probability, magnitude, and age group (F8,624 ¼ 2.12, p ¼ 0.032) on AR, between probability and age group (F4,312 ¼ 6.18, p < 0.001), between magnitude and age group (F2,156 ¼ 7.76, p < 0.001), and between probability and magnitude (F8,624 ¼ 15.18, p < 0.001), as well as signiﬁcant main effects of age group (F1,78 ¼ 5.90, p ¼ 0.017), probability (F4,312 ¼ 848.67, p < 0.001), and magnitude (F2,156 ¼ 5.86, p ¼ 0.003). Post hoc comparisons parsing out the 3-way interaction effect showed signiﬁcantly higher ARs in older than younger adults in the MMM (t603.58 ¼ 3.44, p ¼ 0.009), MMH (t603.58 ¼ 3.39, p ¼ 0.011), MLM (t603.58 ¼ 3.99, p ¼ 0.001), MLH (t603.58 ¼ 3.80, p ¼ 0.002), LLM (t603.58 ¼ 3.17, p ¼ 0.024), and LLH (t603.58 ¼ 3.76, p ¼ 0.003) conditions. Thus, while young adults losing and higher reduced ARs to increasing probabilities of  magnitudes of cost constituting the trial EVs, older adults accepted more middle to lower probability stakes than younger adults particularly as the magnitude of points became more tempting, albeit unfavorable.  Analysis of RTs also revealed age differences particularly in lower probability conditions (Supplementary Fig. S2). Repeated measures ANOVA yielded signiﬁcant interactions between probability and age group (F4,312 ¼ 3.42, p ¼ 0.009), and between probability and magnitude (F8,624 ¼ 4.53, p < 0.001), but showed no interaction between magnitude and age group (F2,156 ¼ 1.15, p ¼ 0.320) and no 3-way interaction (F8,624 ¼ 1.09, p ¼ 0.368). Main effects were signiﬁcant for age group (F1,78 ¼ 20.62, p < 0.001), probability (F4,312 ¼ 79.75, p < 0.001), but not magnitude (F2,156 ¼ 1.01, p ¼ 0.366). Because, not surprisingly, older adults showed typical general slowing of RTs compared with younger adults, and there were no age interaction effects with magnitude, post hoc evaluations focused on within-group pairwise comparisons of probability effects. These showed signiﬁcant RT increases from low to middle probabilities (ML*eMM*: t312 ¼ ␀4.13, p < 0.001; LL*eML*: t312 ¼ ␀2.86, p ¼ 0.046) and RT decreases from middle to high probabilities (MM*eMH*: t312 ¼ 7.01, p < 0.001; MH*eHH*: t312 ¼ 5.19, p < 0.001) in younger adults. By contrast, older adults showed less RT differences from low to middle probabilities (ML*eMM*: t312 ¼ ␀2.12; p ¼ 0.346.; LL*eML*: t312 ¼ ␀1.19, p ¼ 1.000) although RTs did signiﬁcantly decrease from middle to high probabilities (MM*eMH*: t312 ¼ 8.13, p < 0.001; MH*eHH*: t312 ¼ 3.23, p ¼ 0.014). Thus, younger adults reduced RTs when stakes were more certain (toward low or high probability conditions), whereas older adults evinced additional deliberation time for taking risks on unfavorable stakes.  3.2. Probability modulated young VS but older VMPFC and MTL  Repeated measures ANOVA of whole-brain functional responses (the main exploratory whole-brain analysis) identiﬁed signiﬁcant interaction effects of age by probability in the right VS, right MTL, VMPFC, DMPFC, and bilateral DLPFC, and age by probability by magnitude in the left putamen, but no age by magnitude effects (Fig. 2A; Supplementary Table S3). Note that the left putamen region is substantially dorsally and laterally displaced in the striatum relative to the right VS region so we treated these as 2 separate functional brain areas. ROI analysis with polynomial contrasts applied in linear mixed models (see Methods) further detailed the speciﬁc age differences in responses to probability and magnitude in these brain areas (Fig. 2BeG; Supplementary Table S4). Consistent with less distinctive responses to value, we found an interaction between age and the linear effect of probability (Problinear; t316 ¼ 2.73, p ¼ 0.007; Fig. 2B) in the right VS due to a positive linear trend in younger (t158 ¼ 2.45, p ¼ 0.015) but not older adults (t476 ¼ ␀1.20, p ¼ 0.233), whose right VS responses were not modulated by probability. Instead, older adults evinced greater sensitivity to increasing probability in right MTL and VMPFC. Speciﬁcally, we found age by Problinear interactions (right MTL: t316 ¼ ␀2.61, p ¼ 0.009; Fig. 2C; VMPFC: t316 ¼ ␀1.96, p ¼ 0.0513; Fig. 2D) driven by linear increases in neural responses to increasing probability in older (right MTL: t158 ¼ 3.12, p ¼ 0.002; VMPFC: t158 ¼ 3.43, p < 0.001) but not younger (right MTL: t158 ¼ ␀0.80, p ¼ 0.426; VMPFC: t158 ¼ 0.07, p ¼ 0.941) adults.  3.3. Higher responses to unfavorable choices in older adult DLPFC and DMPFC  Bilateral DLPFC and DMPFC responded with higher neural activity as probability of losing increased (or as probability of winning decreased in the mixed lotteries) in older but not younger adults  Y.-S. Speciﬁcally, bilateral DLPFC and DMPFC showed age by Problinear interactions (left DLPFC: t316 ¼ 3.35, p < 0.001; right DLPFC: t316 ¼ 2.24, p ¼ 0.026; DMPFC: t316 ¼ 2.51, p ¼ 0.013) qualiﬁed by negative Problinear response trends indicating increasing neural activity to increasing probability of losing in older adults (left DLPFC: t158 ¼ ␀3.89, p < 0.001; right DLPFC: t158 ¼ ␀2.52, p ¼ 0.013; DMPFC: t158 ¼ ␀4.14, p < 0.001) but not younger (left DLPFC: t158 ¼ 1.25, p ¼ 0.213; right DLPFC: t158 ¼ 1.05, p ¼ 0.295; DMPFC: t158 ¼ 0.280, p ¼ 0.781) adults. Supplementary model-based fMRI analysis treating probability and magnitude as continuous and performed separately for each age group corroborated the previously mentioned ﬁndings on age differences in brain areas showing neural sensitivity to probability. Speciﬁcally, linear probability-related neural responses shifted from the VS in younger adults to MTL and frontal areas in older adults (Supplementary Fig. S3A).  Interestingly, we found interaction effects between the quadratic neural responses to probability (Probquadratic) and age in bilateral DLPFC ROIs such that younger adults showed inverted Ushaped responses across probability conditions in contrast to linearly increasing neural responses to lower probability conditions in older adults (young vs. old; left DLPFC: t316 ¼ ␀2.28, p ¼ 0.023; right DLPFC: t316 ¼ ␀2.89, p ¼ 0.004; Fig. 2EeF, Supplementary Table S3 and Supplementary Fig. S3A, C). Analysis of the left putamen ROI also yielded similar results as in the DLPFC ROIs. Speciﬁcally, left putamen responses showed enhanced inverted U-shaped Probquadratic neural responses particularly to increasing magnitudes, in young but not older adults, who again showed less distinctive responses across choice EV conditions in this striatal area (young vs. old: t794 ¼ ␀2.09, p ¼ 0.037; young: t397 ¼ ␀2.87, p ¼ 0.004; old: t555 ¼ ␀0.526, p ¼ 0.599; Supplementary Fig. S4B). Note, unlike the  192  Y.-S. Su et al. / Neurobiology of Aging 69 (2018) 185e198  right VS, the left putamen did not evince signiﬁcant Problinear neural responses at the group level (Supplementary Table S4), supporting our approach to treat these brain areas as functionally distinct. Thus, bilateral DLPFC and left putamen responses reﬂect more neural engagement during middle (relative to high and low) probability conditions in younger adults, particularly at higher stake magnitudes. Such a neural response proﬁle is consistent with greater decision difﬁculty inducing greater cognitive control when relying on a p ¼ 50% (or EV ¼ 0) strategy, especially when stakes increase. This neural response proﬁle is also in contrast to the linear increase in DLPFC and DMPFC neural responses as probability to lose increased in older adults, indicative of a different decision strategy compared with younger adults. Modulation of neural activity in relation to the main effect of magnitude was observed in several brain areas but these were minimally affected by age (Supplementary Table S3 and Fig. S3B).  3.4. Frontostriatal neural sensitivity to probability mediates age effects on risk-taking  Correlations between ROI neural sensitivity to P (regression coefﬁcients for P from the supplementary model-based fMRI analysis) and decision behavior were evaluated (Fig. 3). In both age  groups, separately as well as the sample as a whole, individuals who had greater neural sensitivity to linear increases in probability of losing (negative linear neural sensitivity to probability of winning) in right VS, DMPFC, and left DLPFC demonstrated more risk-taking behavior, with lower adjusted DT scores (greater acceptance for more loss dominant stakes) (Fig. 3AeC). This correlation between greater linear neural sensitivity to probability of losing with lower DT across individuals was additionally signiﬁcant in the right DLPFC and left putamen in young adults, with the right DLPFC correlation also signiﬁcant for the sample as a whole (Fig. 3D, Supplementary Fig. S4C). However, linear regressions performed for each ROI failed to yield any signiﬁcant interaction effects of linear neural probability sensitivity and age on DT (right VS: t76 ¼ ␀1.10, p ¼ 0.277; DMPFC: t76 ¼ ␀0.95; p ¼ 0.343; left DLPFC: t76 ¼ ␀0.79; p ¼ 0.435; right DLPFC: t76 ¼ 0.51; p ¼ 0.614; left putamen: t76 ¼ 1.37; p ¼ 0.176). Thus, individual linear neural sensitivity to probability in these ROIs was associated with DT, and age did not modulate these brain-behavior correlations.  We then evaluated whether greater linear negative neural sensitivity to probability in these ROIs during the LCT mediated the effect of age on DTs. We applied a mediation model to test the indirect effect of age on DT via simultaneous multiple ROI linear neural probability sensitivities Fig S5,  Section 2.5;  (see  p Þ in (A) the right VS, (B) DMPFC, (C) left DLPFC, and (D) right DLPFC in young (orange) and older adults (blue). Correlation coefﬁcients (r) are shown for young (Y), ﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃ DT  Fig. 3. Scatterplots depicting correlations between individual neural sensitivity to linear increases in probability (regression coefﬁcient for P from model-based fMRI analysis) and adjusted DTs ð old (O), and for both age groups together (All), along with the slope coefﬁcients (b with SEM in parentheses) of regression lines. * denotes p < 0.05 (uncorrected), ** denotes p < 0.05 (adjusted for FDR). Abbreviations: DMPFC, dorsomedial prefrontal cortex; DLPFC, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex; DT, decision threshold; FDR, false discovery rate; VS, ventral striatum. (For interpretation of the references to color in this ﬁgure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)  Y.-S. Su et al. / Neurobiology of Aging 69 (2018) 185e198  193  Supplementary Table S5A). Signiﬁcant indirect effects of age on DT were found for left DLPFC (Z ¼ 2.74, p ¼ 0.006) and right VS (Z ¼ 2.18, p ¼ 0.029) with a marginal negative effect of right DLPFC (Z ¼ ␀1.86, p ¼ 0.063). Note that indirect effects of age on DT were also all signiﬁcant except for left putamen even when ROIs were considered in separate mediation models (Supplementary Table S5B). Thus, greater risk-taking with age operated through greater negative neural probability sensitivity in the right VS and left DLPFC with somewhat reduced right DLPFC involvement in older compared with younger adults.  3.5. Associations between resting-state and LCT functional connectivity of ROIs with risk-taking behavior in young and older adults  Given the aforementioned age differences in brain regions engaged for processing probability during the LCT, we further evaluated how baseline resting-state and task-related functional communication between the different neural networks in young and older adults were associated with LCT performance. We ﬁrst examined young and older adult DT associations with baseline RSFC between the ROIs identiﬁed in the main whole-brain analysis previously mentioned (Supplementary Fig. S6). During resting state (Fig. 4A, B), in younger adults, lower DT was associated only with lower functional connectivity between left putamen and left DLPFC. By contrast, in older adults, lower DT correlated with lower functional connectivity between left putamen and left DLPFC, between right VS and left DLPFC, and between right VS and right DLPFC. Linear regression analysis revealed a signiﬁcant interaction effect of age with right VS and left DLPFC RSFC on DT (t75 ¼ ␀2.36, p ¼ 0.021). Speciﬁcally, higher individual baseline RSFC between the right VS and left DLPFC was associated with higher DTs in older but not in younger adults. Furthermore, note that right VS and left DLPFC were functionally disconnected (mean RSFC was not significantly different from zero) in older adults as a group during baseline resting state (see Supplementary Fig. S6).  We then examined young and older adult DT associations with functional connectivity during the LCT task (LCTFC) between the same identiﬁed ROIs (Supplementary Fig. S6; Fig. 4C, D). In young adults, lower DT was associated with lower functional connectivity between left putamen and right MTL. By contrast, in older adults, lower DT correlated with lower functional connectivity between the left and right DLPFC, and between DMPFC and right MTL. Linear regressions revealed a marginal interaction effect of age with bilateral DLPFC LCTFC on DT (t76 ¼ ␀1.80, p ¼ 0.075). Note that LCT functional connectivity between bilateral DLPFC was signiﬁcantly lower in older than younger adults with aging (Supplementary Fig. S6).  3.6. Age modulates the effect of DLPFC-VS RSFC on LCT risk-taking behavior via mediation by LCT task functional connectivity  That frontostriatal RSFC modulated individual decision behavior more in older than younger adults suggests age effects on baseline functional communication in this network that may underlie the changes in the broader network engaged by older adults during the LCT task. Thus, we applied a moderated mediation analysis to evaluate age modulation of the effect of baseline resting-state frontostriatal functional connectivity on LCT decision behavior mediated by network functional connectivity during the LCT task. We focused on functional connections with any evidence for age differences in associations with DT from the aforementioned correlation analyses that included RSFC between right VS and left DLPFC as the primary causal effect, and LCTFC between left DLPFC and right DLPFC, between right MTL and DMPFC (where  p ﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃﬃ DT  correlations reached signiﬁcance in older but not younger adults), and between left putamen and right MTL (where correlations reach signiﬁcance in younger but not older adults) as mediators. We also hypothesized that older adults should have stronger mediation than younger adults of MTL and frontal processing during the LCT. Results and details of the moderated mediation coefﬁcients are shown in Fig. 5 and Supplementary Table S6 (coefﬁcient means (SEM) of key effects are highlighted here in the main text). As expected, the model showed a signiﬁcant direct effect of right VS and left DLPFC RSFC on DT (mean (SEM) ¼ 2.97 (1.13); Z ¼ 2.62, p ¼ 0.004, 1-tailed; see Supplementary Table S6, c0). To provide an anchor then, a unit change in right VS and left DLPFC RSFC (which are Fisher Z-transformed correlations; see Methods) was proportional to a change in by 2.97, after accounting for the mediation variables. For young adults, there was only a marginal further negative indirect effect of the left DLPFC and right DLPFC LCTFC mediation (mean (SEM) ¼ ␀0.517 (0.402); Z ¼ ␀1.29, p ¼ 0.099, 1tailed; Supplementary Table S6, indirect effect for young adults for M2) of the aforementioned direct effect. In older adults, the aforementioned direct effect was signiﬁcantly positively mediated by left DLPFC and right DLPFC LCTFC (mean (SEM) ¼ 0.909 (0.540); Z ¼ 1.68, p ¼ 0.046, 1-tailed) and a marginal effect of DMPFC and right MTL LCTFC (mean (SEM) ¼ 0.941 (0.622); Z ¼ 1.51, p ¼ 0.066, 1tailed) (Supplementary Table S6, indirect effects for older adults for M2 and M3). Critically, age (young vs. older) signiﬁcantly moderated the mediation effects of the LCTFC between the left and right DLPFC (mean (SEM) ¼ ␀0.713 (0.370); Z ¼ ␀1.93, p ¼ 0.027, 1tailed), and between DMPFC and right MTL (mean (SEM) ¼ ␀0.771 (0.424); Z ¼ ␀1.82, p ¼ 0.035, 1-tailed) (Supplementary Table S6, effect of moderated mediation for M2 and M3). Evaluation of the aforementioned moderated mediation model based on simultaneous multiple mediators using separate models for each mediator yielded similar results (Supplementary Table S7).  4. Discussion  Our ﬁndings demonstrate a systemic neurofunctional difference in the way the older human adult brain approaches mixed-lottery choice decisions relative to young adults. Instead of directly engaging a more rudimentary VS-based stimulus-response selection in reaction to EV as in young adults, older adults evinced greater involvement across MTL, ventral and dorsal medial prefrontal, and bilateral lateral prefrontal areas that implicate more affective-like reactions and higher regulatory control. Critically, comprehensive analyses of various aspects of our brain and behavioral data provide support for the notion that age-related shift to involve more MTL and frontal processing of mixed-lottery choices underlies greater behavioral propensity to accept unfavorable stakes in older compared with younger adults. Speciﬁcally, altered neural sensitivity to losing stakes in bilateral DLPFC and right VS mediated the effect of greater age in increasing LCT risktaking. In addition, the engagement of LCT functional connectivity between left and right DLPFC and between right MTL and DMPFC in mediating the effect of baseline frontostriatal RSFC on risk-taking was more evident in older than in younger adults.  Several results in this present study comparing older (aged 59e78 years old) with younger (aged 20e29 years old) adult age groups are consistent with our previous study focusing on older individuals aged 55e80 years old (Goh et al., 2016). In both studies, mean LCT DTs in older adults as a group were in the negative EV range indicating an overall risk-taking preference, with this present study also showing that the DT was signiﬁcantly lower compared with that for younger adults. RTs were also slower for both older adult groups as EVs became more negative in both studies, particularly for more extreme risk-taking older individuals in Goh et al.  194  Y.-S. Neural activity during older adult choice processing in this study increased with increasing stake probability in VMPFC and with increasing stake magnitude (but not probability) in bilateral ventral striatal areas, similar to our previous ﬁnding of increasing neural activity with increasing EV in these same brain areas. Finally, in both studies, older adult neural activity in bilateral lateral and dorsomedial prefrontal areas increased to decreasing EV or increasing probability of losing. Such replication of older adult behavioral and frontostriatal responses to valuative information in mixed-lottery choices further accentuates the differences in comparison with younger adults in this present study, who showed more risk-neutral behavior and ventral striatal sensitivity to stake probability.  Interestingly, although our previous study showed older adult MTL neural activity during the LCT decreased with increasing EV (and also increasing probability), MTL responses in this present study increased with increasing probability. We suggest that this difference in mean neural sensitivity to valuative information across older adult groups reﬂects the substantial heterogeneity of individual differences in MTL responses. Indeed, the previous study  found MTL responses ranged from having positive to negative associations with increasing EV across a much larger sample of riskaverse to risk-taking older individuals, respectively. Critically, evaluation of older individuals in that study revealed that although individuals with extreme risk-taking preferences showed negative neural sensitivity to EV in MTL responses, more moderately risktaking individuals showed minimum to positive MTL neural EV sensitivity. Thus, the negative mean MTL sensitivity to EV in the previous study may have been driven by more individuals with extreme risk-taking preferences sampled in that larger cohort in contrast to the positive mean MTL sensitivity to probability in older adults in this study, which might reﬂect relatively moderate risk-taking preferences in this present older adult sample. Nevertheless, in both studies, MTL sensitivity to value plays a more prominent role in older adult risk-taking decisions compared with younger adults. Taken together, the ﬁndings from these 2 studies provide complementary views of young and older adult group differences in neural responses associated with valuative processing of choices as well as older adult individual differences in these age-related effects.  196  Y.-S. Su et al. / Neurobiology of Aging 69 (2018) 185e198  Previous studies on age differences in value-based decisionmaking have reported mixed-ﬁndings on whether older adults are more or less risk-taking compared with younger adults. Metaanalysis across studies revealed that the mixed ﬁndings were largely due to task differences in the dependence on learning and memory, and framing of the decision context (Best and Charness, 2015; Mata et al., 2011). Not surprisingly, age differences are generally detected when the decision task required retrieval of past outcome histories. Importantly, in studies where probabilities are made explicit and learning from past outcomes are not required, the effects of age in risk preferences also differed if current choices are framed as potential gains, potential losses, or mixed (Pachur et al., 2017; Rutledge et al., 2016; Tymula et al., 2013). Speciﬁcally, for gain-only probabilistic lotteries, older adults showed greater risk-aversion than younger adults (Rutledge et al., 2016; Tymula et al., 2013). By contrast, for loss-only lotteries, older adults evinced greater risk-taking than younger adults (Tymula et al., 2013; albeit Rutledge et al., 2016 found no age differences). Critically, Rutledge et al. (2016) also evaluated mixed lotteries similar to our LCT in which choices in each trial were between a sure outcome or a simultaneous chance of gain or loss (with no null outcomes) and found higher risk-taking in older than younger adults, consistent with our results. It should be noted, however, that older adults may have a higher preference for certainty compared with younger adults in choices that involve sure versus probabilistic outcomes as in the previously mentioned studies, perhaps due to the reduced cognitive effort to process the former (Mather et al., 2012). Controlling for this, Pachur et al. (2017) presented young and older adults with 2 lottery options in each trial with different variable magnitudes and probabilities constituting EV and risk differences between the options. Computational modeling of their behavioral decision data revealed lower loss aversion (overweighting of losing EVs) and greater optimism of potential gains (overweighting of the probability of winning; see Hess, 2015) in older compared with younger adults, consistent with the higher acceptance rates for unfavorable mixed lotteries (low probability of winning high magnitudes) in older than younger adults in our study. In light of these prior studies, we highlight that our LCT task stimuli were straightforward texts that bypassed the need to translate from graphical representations of value as might be used in other studies, given age effects on perceptual processing (Goh et al., 2010; Park et al., 2004). The zero outcome for rejected lotteries also allows us to determine a more neutral certainty equivalence using estimated individual DTs. Finally, the LCT task favors decisions made solely on information given during each trial and discourages reliance on past reward history. Thus, although our paradigm favors more objective and risk-neutral decisions, we still ﬁnd that older adults display greater risk-taking behavior than younger adults. Overall, the emergent ﬁnding integrating across past studies and ours is that, barring cognitive demand and reward framing inﬂuences, older adults engage greater risk-taking behavior than younger adults particularly for unfavorable stakes in mixed lottery decisions. Critically, we add to extant behavioral literature by showing that this age-related change in risky behavior for mixedlotteries is associated with a shift in brain central processing of value from striatal areas in younger adults to more medial temporal and frontal areas in older adults.  It may be counter-intuitive that increased medial temporal and frontal activity that we interpret to reﬂect greater affective-like modulation and control is associated with greater risk-taking in older adult decision-making. We note, however, that increased control-related neural activity in older adults has been indicative of the heightened need for compensatory neural recruitment to cope with underlying declines in more primary neural processes (Goh, 2013; Hakun et al., 2015; Schneider-Garces et al., 2010; Zhu et al.,  2014) (5, 35e37). In line with a positivity bias (Mather and Carstensen, 2005) and the behavioral ﬁndings in Pachur et al. (2017), increased frontal and medial temporal activity for unfavorable lotteries in older adults is also consistent with greater neural processing engaged to regulate negative affect associated with losing prospects compared with the positive affect for more favorable prospects. Alternatively, higher medial temporal and frontal activity in older adults may reﬂect different motivations than younger adults, such as greater salience for winning under unfavorable rather than favorable odds, when making lottery decisions. These cases are not mutually exclusive and are consistent with age-related positivity bias and changes in the neural processing of goals and values (Samanez-Larkin and Knutson, 2015). We acknowledge, however, that our experiment only evaluates agerelated differences in neural and behavioral responses to different probabilities and magnitudes. As such, future studies that examine neural processes associated with speciﬁc motivations behind older adult value-based decisions and direct modulations of emotional reactions during decision processing are required to elucidate this issue.  That age effects were largely seen in neural processing of probability but not magnitude in our results agrees with studies that found age effects using tasks involving probability in decisions (Dreher et al., 2008), and those that found preservation in neural responses in older adults using tasks that did not involve probability (Lorenz et al., 2014; Samanez-Larkin et al., 2007, 2014). We speculate that such modulation of neural responses to probability but not magnitude reﬂects the speciﬁc inﬂuence of age on certainty processing in older adult value-based decisions (Mather et al., 2012) as well as distinct neuronal ﬁring patterns to different components of EV (Fiorillo et al., 2003). Speciﬁcally, in our experiment, neural coding of increasing magnitude might be more concrete and can be directly instantiated via increases in neuronal population activity that thereby scale the salience of other concurrent neural processes. By contrast, apart from such quantitative modulation of neuronal population activity, neural coding of the probability of winning or losing likely also involves more qualitative access to different beliefs about probability (Ma and Jazayeri, 2014). For this reason, neural coding of probability might be more susceptible to agerelated changes in the use of strategies that emphasize the subjective meaning, and thus framing (e.g., 10% chance of winning vs. 90% chance of losing), of a given probability.  In our study, baseline RSFC between the left DLPFC and right VS predicted older adult DTs during the LCT more than younger adults. This ﬁnding supports the association between older adult reward learning and ventromedial prefrontal to striatal structural connectivity (Samanez-Larkin et al., 2012), and suggests that the baseline efﬁcacy of frontostriatal communication is an important determinant of older adult decision neural processing and decision behavior. Indeed, the role functional connectivity between left and right DLPFC and between right MTL and VMPFC during the LCT in mediating the effect of frontostriatal baseline RSFC on DTs was more evident in older than younger adults. Thus, apart from the inﬂuence of psychological differences in motivation and affective processing between young and older adults, we also provide evidence on more neurobiological aspects of brain aging that jointly contribute to older adult decision-making as well. Further work that comprehensively integrate white-matter tract and fMRI data in longitudinal studies are required to more precisely characterize how age changes in brain structural connections conduct dynamic functional communication between frontal and striatal brain regions that then bear on older adult information processing associated with decision behaviors.  Finally, and more broadly, it is intriguing to consider whether responding to veridical EV is always the optimal approach when  Y.-S. Su et al. / Neurobiology of Aging 69 (2018) 185e198  197  interacting with the environment from the perspective of the human species as a whole. With age comes wisdom (Worthy et al., 2011) and extended prior subjective experiences with the environment. For humans, relative to other species, this experience can be communicated via stable and also complex means within and across generations. This suggests that as a species with rich social tools, humans can more effectively harness information about longterm environmental contingencies compared with more instantaneous snapshots of immediate contexts. Thus, the neural processes underlying the change in goals with age jointly reﬂect the effects of senescent neural functioning as well as cohort-wise assessments of environmental utilities. Individual differences across older adult value-based decision-making (Goh et al., 2016) then stand as critical indicators of the effects of the environment in relation to speciﬁc biological limitations. For instance, the human species did not much have to contend with issues of Alzheimer’s Disease (and other age-related cognitive declines implicated in frontal, striatal, and medial temporal functioning) until recent increases in life expectancy (Vaupel, 2010). In this light, we recommend that longitudinal studies are critical for investigations on broader economic implications surrounding aging human neural processing of value-based decisions.
