All rights reserved.  R.F. Titcombe-Parekh et al.  Table 1 Neural circuitry of PTSD.  Neural Circuit  Brain Structures  Emotion Regulation and Executive Function Threat and Salience Detection Contextual Processing Fear Learning  dlPFC, vlPFC, mPFC ACC, Insula, Amygdala mPFC, Thalamus, Hippocampus BLA, CeAM, CeAL  Note. dlPFC = dorsolateral prefrontal cortex; vlPFC = ventrolateral prefrontal cortex; mPFC = medial prefrontal cortex; ACC = anterior cingulate cortex; BLA = basolateral complex of the amygdala; CeAM = medial central nucleus of the amygdala; CeAL = lateral central nucleus of the amygdala.  been associated with abnormalities in the amygdala, which are believed to underlie the acquisition of fear learning and failure to extinguish fear. Abnormalities in amygdala functioning in PTSD have been attributed to deﬁcits in fear extinction, safety learning, and extinction recall (Jovanovic et al., 2012; Milad et al., 2009). Threat detection, characterized by attentional biases to threatening stimuli, hypervigilance, and exaggerated startle, has been linked with alterations in the amygdala, the dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC), and the insula (Seeley et al., 2007). Alterations in emotional regulation and executive function are associated with decreased engagement of the dorsolateral (dlPFC), ventrolateral (vlPFC) and dorsomedial (dmPFC) prefrontal cortex in clinical and non-clinical studies (e.g. Buhle et al., 2014; Ochsner et al., 2012). Furthermore, studies with PTSD patients have found reduced connectivity within the fronto-parietal regions, which is believed to be associated with impaired executive functioning (Sripada et al., 2012). Contextual processing appears to be impaired in PTSD contributing to diﬃculty distinguishing between safe and threatening stimuli. Functional brain imaging research has shown the ability to distinguish between safety and threat cues is supported by signaling between the mPFC and the hippocampus (Lang et al., 2009), and studies have found volumetric and functional abnormalities of the hippocampus among individuals with PTSD (e.g. Pitman et al., 2012; Shin and Liberzon, 2010). Additionally, alterations in signaling in the mPFC have been shown to interfere with the processing of contextual information, to learning (Rougemont-Bücking et al., 2011).  impaired safety-signal  and contribute  Among factors that might help to better understand the engagement of neural circuits in the pathogenesis of PTSD is human self-regulation in response to stress and trauma. It has been well documented that in the wake a traumatic event, perceptions of the self may be altered (e.g. Benight and Bandura, 2004; Ehlers and Clarke, 2000), and numerous studies have found that maladaptive perceptions of one's self are strongly associated with PTSD (Bryant and Guthrie, 2007; Dekel et al., 2013). Negative changes in self-appraisals may be a critical mechanism underlying PTSD as it relates to one's ability to engage in self-regulatory processes, which facilitate adaptions to stress and trauma. According to Social Cognitive Theory (SCT), the capacity to adapt to stress depends, in part, on one's ability to successfully employ personal (adaptive cognitive appraisals), environmental (social support), and behavioral (proactive coping) strategies that facilitate goal attainment and a sense of agency.  Self-appraisals about one's ability to respond to stress may then lead to development of self-eﬃcacy perceptions around coping (Benight and Bandura, 2004). There is considerable evidence suggesting that selfeﬃcacy inﬂuences how individuals respond to potentially traumatic events (for a review see Benight and Bandura, 2004). Self-eﬃcacy is described as one's self-perceived ability to inﬂuence command over personal thoughts, behaviors, and emotions, as well as the external environment (Bandura, 1997). Lower levels of self-eﬃcacy have been associated with PTSD among a wide range of trauma-exposed populations (e.g. Benight and Bandura, 2004; Bosmans and Van der Velden, 2015; Cieslak et al., 2008; Ehlers et al., 1998a,b; Piotrkowski and  59  Journal of Psychiatric Research 104 (2018) 58–64  Brannen, 2002; Saigh et al., 1995; Solomon et al., 1991). In addition, experimental research has found that increasing perceptions of self-efﬁcacy leads to more adaptive cognitive and aﬀective processing when exposed to stress (Geer et al., 1970; Glass et al., 1973; Litt et al., 1993; Sanderson et al., 1989). Importantly, self-eﬃcacy may also be an important mechanism underlying recovery, as low levels of self-eﬃcacy have been associated with poor treatment outcome (e.g. Ehlers et al., 1998a,b).  Of particular relevance to the treatment of PTSD, an emerging body of research is showing perceptions of self-eﬃcacy in coping can be manipulated, and doing so leads to improved performance on cognitive and aﬀective processes that may aid in recovery from PTSD. For example, in two studies with healthy controls, Brown and colleagues (Brown et al., 2012a, 2012b) used a false feedback technique in which participants were told that, in response to a stressful event, they were either in the top 1% or bottom 30% of copers. Although the two groups did not diﬀer on levels of self-eﬃcacy before the induction, those in the high self-eﬃcacy condition self-reported signiﬁcantly higher levels of self-eﬃcacy after the experimenter feedback. Following this induction, participants generated autobiographical memories and imagined personal future events with greater episodic speciﬁcity (2012a), performed better on a social problem-solving task (2012a), and reported fewer visual intrusions and less distress following a trauma ﬁlm-paradigm (2012b). In addition, Zlomuzica et al. (2015) employed a similar falsefeedback technique in healthy individuals before a fear conditioning task, and found that self-eﬃcacy induction facilitated extinction learning as measured by self-report and electrodermal activity.  In an eﬀort to increase self-eﬃcacy in clinical populations without utilizing false-feedback, Brown et al. (2016) recently demonstrated that self-eﬃcacy can be increased through the recall of autobiographical memories of successful coping. In a sample of OEF/OIF combat veterans with and without PTSD, participants were randomized to either a high self-eﬃcacy or control condition. Those in the high self-eﬃcacy condition were asked to recall three autobiographical memories associated with times they demonstrated successful coping, whereas in the control condition they were asked to recall any three important memories. Participants in the high self-eﬃcacy condition subsequently reported higher levels of self-eﬃcacy. In addition, those in the high self-eﬃcacy condition imagined future events characterized by greater agency and demonstrated better performance on a military-related social-problem solving task (Brown et al., 2016). Employing a similar method for increasing self-eﬃcacy through autobiographical memory, Morina et al. (2017) showed that torture survivors asked to recall self-eﬃcacy related memories exhibited greater distress tolerance on a mirror-tracing task. Such ﬁndings suggest that increasing self-eﬃcacy may help to engage cognitive processes adaptive for recovery.  However, studies have yet to examine whether increasing levels of self-eﬃcacy may lead to neural changes associated with recovery. Speciﬁcally, this study aimed to test whether using autobiographical memory self-eﬃcacy induction (Brown et al., 2016) would lead to changes within four neural circuits that have been implicated in PTSD (Shalev et al., 2017). Brain imaging research with healthy individuals and PTSD populations would suggest that experimental manipulations aimed to increase self-regulatory processes, such as perceptions of selfeﬃcacy, would engage the prefrontal cortex (e.g. Curtis & D'Esposito, 2003; Heatherton, 2011; Goldberg, 2001; Miller and Cohen, 2001). Considerable work has found that ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC), lateral prefrontal cortex (lPFC), and the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) play key roles in self-regulation in response to aﬀective stimuli (for a review see Heatherton, 2011). Moreover, neuroimaging studies of emotion regulation have consistently found that the PFC is engaged in top-down regulatory processes when individuals are attempting to regulate responses to negative stimuli (e.g. Davidson et al., 2000; Ochsner et al., 2004; Ochsner and Gross, 2005). Therefore, although the four neural circuits proposed by Shalev et al. (2017) were examined in this study, it was predicted that changes in the emotional  R.F. Titcombe-Parekh et al.  Journal of Psychiatric Research 104 (2018) 58–64  regulation and executive function (ER/EF) circuit were most likely to be associated with an increase in self-eﬃcacy.  To investigate the potential impact of self-eﬃcacy on the four neural circuits associated with PTSD, graph-theory network analysis was utilized to examine the topological properties of brain networks (e.g. Bassett and Bullmore, 2006). Graph theory has been translated and applied to model the brain as a complex network represented by sets of nodes and edges (Bullmore and Sporns, 2009; Wang et al., 2016). Studies of healthy individuals employing graph theory have shown that human brain networks exhibit many complex organizational features, including small-worldness (a brain network characterized by high efﬁciency of information transfer at a low cost) and modularity (the partition of a brain network into smaller functional communities of modules, Achard et al., 2006; He et al., 2007). Graph theory analyses have also been able to distinguish psychiatric from healthy individuals in numerous studies (Bassett et al., 2012; Leistedt et al., 2009; Lynall et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2011). For example, compared to traumaexposed individuals without PTSD, PTSD patients exhibit decreased path length, as well as increased clustering coeﬃcient, global eﬃciency and local eﬃciency (Lei et al., 2015). Additionally, a recent study of adolescent females with PTSD found that greater network modularity and assortativity, as well as lesser eﬃciency were associated with better response to treatment (Cisler et al., 2016). In contrast, a recent study of children diagnosed with PTSD showed an increase in path length, and decreased local and global eﬃciency (Suo et al., 2015). The authors suggest that diﬀerences in ﬁndings may be related to the way in which stress aﬀects the brain at diﬀerent stages of human development, which warrants further research (Suo et al., 2015).  This study is the ﬁrst to look at whether recalling autobiographical memories of self-eﬃcacy may have the potential to alter neural circuits associated with PTSD pathology. OEF/OIF combat veterans with PTSD were randomized to either a high self-eﬃcacy induction (HSE) in which they recalled autobiographical memories related to self-eﬃcacy or a no self-eﬃcacy induction (NSE) control condition. Functional MRI (fMRI) was then used to measure resting state functional connectivity (rsFC) in previously identiﬁed neural circuits functioning in fear learning, threat detection, emotional regulation and executive function, and contextual processing. Although meta-analyses provide a powerful method for identifying alterations in resting state activity in PTSD (e.g. Disner et al., 2018; Hayes et al., 2012; Koch et al., 2016; Patel et al., 2012; Ramage et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2016), due to the heterogeneity of ﬁndings, the regions of interest in this study were based on those neural circuits identiﬁed in the framework proposed by Shalev et al. (2017). This model speciﬁcally aims to link abnormalities in neural circuits with the core symptom clusters in PTSD aﬀording it potential utility as a conceptual and empirical guide in the apriori identiﬁcation of speciﬁc dysregulated circuits to be used in the assessment of interventions (Sheynin and Liberzon, 2017).  Two network measures of brain connectivity, average connectivity and path length, were analyzed for each circuit to assess for changes associated with high self-eﬃcacy induction in participants. Given previous ﬁndings from graph theory analyses showing that PTSD was associated with decreased path length and greater connectivity, it was predicted that increasing self-eﬃcacy among individuals with PTSD would be associated with reduced connectivity and greater path length. Furthermore, although this hypothesis was examined in all four neural circuits, given previous ﬁndings on the primary role of the prefrontal cortex in self-regulation, it was expected that these patterns would be most evident in the ER/EF circuit.  2. Method  2.1. Participants  Thirty-four male OEF/OIF combat veterans with PTSD were recruited for this study. Veterans were recruited from the Mental Health  60  Services of the Manhattan, Bronx and Brooklyn Veterans Aﬀairs Medical Centers, other regional VA medical centers, Veterans Service Organizations, National Guard, reservist agencies and organizations, and from the general community. Recruitment methods included ﬂyers, in-person presentations, media advertisements, internet postings (e.g. Craigslist), and referrals from clinicians. Participants were excluded if they had a life-time history of psychosis, bipolar disorder, major depression with psychotic features, or were less than two months stable on psychotropic medications. Participants received $100 USD for their participation.  considered  positive  for PTSD if  Participants were  their Posttraumatic Diagnostic Scale (PDS, Foa, 1995) score was ≥24, and they reported impairment for at least one month (Sheeran and Zimmerman, 2002). Half of the participants were randomized to the HSE induction and half were randomized to the NSE control condition. All subjects provided informed written consent for this protocol, which was approved by NYU School of Medicine Institutional Review Board.  2.2. Procedure  Prior to scanning, participants completed clinical self-report measures including the General Self-Eﬃcacy Scale (GSE, Schwarzer and Jerusalem, 1995), the Combat Exposure Scale (CES, Keane et al., 1989), the Posttraumatic Diagnostic Scale (PDS, Foa, 1995), and the Beck Depression Inventory-second edition (BDI-II, Beck et al., 1996) (Table 2).  Veterans with PTSD were randomized to HSE induction or NSE control condition. Following the protocol of Brown et al. (2016), in the HSE induction, subjects were asked to recall in detail three autobiographical memories reﬂecting times when they demonstrated high self-eﬃcacy. The experimenter then summarized the recollected event emphasizing the strengths exhibited by the subject at that time, and had the subject also reﬂect on these strengths. NSE control subjects were asked to recall three signiﬁcant life events, and did not engage in speciﬁc reﬂections of strengths and successes. Given that the NSE did not receive additional feedback about their self-eﬃcacy memories, in order to control for contact time with the experimenter, the experimenter spent an additional 5 min providing general information about the MRI procedure with each participant in the NSE condition. All participants then underwent MRI scan to collect resting-state fMRI data.  2.3. MRI data acquisition  The resting-state fMRI data were acquired on a 3T MRI scanner (Skyra, Siemens, 20-ch head coil) with Echo Planar Imaging (EPI) sequence: repetition time 2000 ms, echo time 30 ms, ﬂip angle 90°, slice number 36, slice thickness 4 mm, slice gap 0, ﬁeld of view 20 cm, matrix size 66 × 66. Anatomical images were acquired using the same scanner with a magnetization prepared rapid gradient echo (MPRAGE) sequence: repetition time 2300 ms, echo time 2.98 ms, ﬂip angle 9°,  Table 2 Demographic and clinical self-report data for OEF/OIF veterans with PTSD.  Variable  High Self-Eﬃcacy Induction  No Self-Eﬃcacy Induction  t  M  26.29 20.35 32.76 20.06 26.29  Age CES GSE BDI-II PDS  SD  8.41 5.64 3.90 9.81 8.41  M  28.44 21.25 33.69 17.94 28.44  SD  9.78 6.73 4.33 10.04 9.78  .68 .68 .64 .61 .68  Note. OIF/OEF = Operation Enduring Freedom/Operation Iraqi Freedom; M = Mean; SD = Standard Deviation; CES = Combat Exposure Scale; GSE = General Self-Eﬃcacy Scale; BDI-II = Beck Depression Inventory Second Edition; PDS = Posttraumatic Stress Disorder Scale.  R.F. Titcombe-Parekh et al.  Journal of Psychiatric Research 104 (2018) 58–64  slice number 192, slice thickness 1 mm, slice gap 0.5 mm, ﬁeld of view 256 × 240 mm, matrix size 256 × 240.  Throughout the scan, subjects were instructed to lay in the scanner supine, awake, and to remain still. Foam pads were inserted to restrict head motion.  2.4. Data preprocessing  The fMRI data was pre-processed with a customized program based on FSL (FMRIB, Oxford) modules, including brain extraction, motion correction and special registration to MNI 152 template with 2 mm voxel size. The ﬁrst ﬁve volumes were removed. The motion correction was conducted using FSL mcFLIRT (http://fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/ fslwiki/MCFLIRT). The data were residualized with respect to six motion parameters estimated from mcFLIRT to account for motion eﬀects. No subject was excluded in our study for excessive head motion. Time points were censored if their displacement was beyond 0.5 mm, and the remaining time points were processed for connectivity measurements. No subject had > 40 censored time points to be completely excluded from the study. Volumes with framewise-displacement of > 0.5 mm were removed from the data to further reduce motion-related artifact. The non-linear registration to MNI 152 template (2 mm voxels) was performed using FSL FNIRT (https://fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslwiki/ FNIRT). Registration from functional to anatomical images was estimated using FSL implementation of boundary-based registration (fsl.fmrib.ox.ac.uk/fsl/fslwiki/FLIRT_BBR).  The ROIs from diﬀerent circuits were located on the template using a predeﬁned atlas or combining labels from Freesurfer (Version 5.3, Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging) (Table 3). The time courses were averaged over the voxels within the same ROIs. The connectivity scores between two ROIs were computed by the Pearson product-moment correlation of corresponding average time courses, and then transformed to Fisher z-scores. Global measurements of network, including average connectivity and average path length, were computed by Brian Connectivity Toolbox (Rubinov and Sporns, 2010).  2.5. Statistical analysis  The group diﬀerences of global network measurements between HSE and NSE subjects were tested with the nonparametric Wilcoxon rank sum tests, carried by the Statistics and Machine Learning Toolbox in Matlab (Version, 2015b; Mathworks Inc.). Analyses did not control for multiple comparisons given the a priori selection of the four neural circuits identiﬁed in the model proposed by Shalev et al. (2017). In addition, the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve was plotted and the area under the curve (AUC) calculated for average connectivity and path length measurements to illustrate performance classiﬁcation. Results  Participant ages ranged from 23 to 51. Regarding race, 46% of participants identiﬁed as White, 30% as Black or African American, 20% as Hispanic, and 3% as Multiracial. Participants in the HSE and NSE conditions did not diﬀer on age or measures of pre-induction selfeﬃcacy. In addition, those in the HSE and NSE did not diﬀer on selfreported levels of combat exposure nor symptom severity of PTSD or depression (p > .05; Table 2).  The mean and 95% conﬁdence interval of network measurements are shown in Figs. 1 and 2. P-values (unadjusted) for group diﬀerences in two global network measurements for the four PTSD neural circuits are shown in Table 4. Among the four circuits, signiﬁcant diﬀerences in network measurements were observed in the right ER/EF circuit (Fig. 3). No signiﬁcant diﬀerences in average connectivity or path length were observed between conditions in the threat and salience  Note. Comparison of HSE and NSE conditions revealed signiﬁcant diﬀerences in both average connectivity and path length in the ER/EF circuit. Speciﬁcally, those in the HSE condition exhibited reduced right-lateralized average connectivity (p < .05) and greater right-lateralized path length (p < .05) in the ER/EF circuit. In addition, AUC analyses found that average connectivity (.71; Fig. 4) and path length (.70; Fig. 5) in right ER/EF moderately predicted HSE group membership.  4. Discussion  These ﬁndings suggest that strategies aimed at increased perceptions of self-eﬃcacy in PTSD may inﬂuence neural circuits associated with emotional regulation and executive function. These results build on a growing body of behavioral studies with clinical and healthy control subjects showing that increasing perceptions of self-eﬃcacy through experimental inductions leads to better performance on various emotional regulation tasks. (Brown et al., 2012a, 2012b; Morina et al., 2018; Zlomuzica et al., 2015).  These ﬁndings also add to the SCT framework emphasizing the importance of self-regulation as a key factor in human adaptation to stress and adversity (Benight and Bandura, 2004). Considerable work has established that maladaptive self-perceptions following trauma play a key role in the onset and maintenance of PTSD. Such negative  Fig. 4. ROC curve of self-eﬃcacy classiﬁcation with average connectivityArea Under the Curve = 0.71.  appraisals are likely to reduce one's ability to successfully cope with trauma as those negative cognitive processes may interfere with internal, social, and behavioral coping strategies, which in turn contribute to low levels of perceived self-eﬃcacy (e.g. Benight et al., 2017). In the context of SCT, high self-eﬃcacy induction may lead to greater self-regulation through the recall of memories associated with goal attainment and agency. Although the construct of self-regulation was not measured in this experiment, SCT theory would predict that individuals will become more successful at regulating responses when they can draw on experiences of mastery to manage current stressors (Bandura, 1997).  The neural diﬀerences observed in the ER/EF circuit between those in the HSE and NSE conditions may be in line with studies comparing individuals with PTSD to controls (Brown et al., 2014; Lei et al., 2015). Path length and functional connectivity have been associated with the transmission of information and functional integration in the brain (e.g. Wang et al., 2009). In other studies, shorter path length has been attributed to an imbalance between local specialization and global  Fig. 3. ROIs in right ER/EF circuit overlaid on structural brain image. Note. Green = dorsolateral prefrontal cortex; Blue = ventrolateral prefrontal cortex; Red = medial prefrontal cortex; ROIs = regions of interest; ER/EF = emotional regulation/executive function.  62  R.F. Titcombe-Parekh et al.  Journal of Psychiatric Research 104 (2018) 58–64  whether the observed changes in neural circuits correspond with selfreported changes in perceived coping capability.  Despite these limitations, this study oﬀers novel ﬁndings as well as possibilities for future research to better understand the relationship between perceptions of self-eﬃcacy and adaptation to adversity and trauma. For example, while this study employed the General SelfEﬃcacy Scale to assess global perceptions of self-eﬃcacy, additional work using the Trauma-Coping Self-Eﬃcacy Scale (CSE-T, Benight et al., 2015) could asses changes in neural circuits associated with perceptions of one's ability to manage speciﬁc demands in the wake of trauma. Additionally, this study examined the impact of a self-eﬃcacy induction on resting state activity, but future task-based fMRI studies will be important to further examine neural responses to the enhancement of self-eﬃcacy in PTSD. Although behavioral studies with healthy and PTSD populations have begun to document some of the positive outcomes associated with experimentally increasing self-eﬃcacy (e.g. Brown et al., 2012a, 2012b; 2016; Morina et al., 2018; Zlomuzica et al., 2015), neural activity in response to emotion regulation and cognitive tasks following a self-eﬃcacy induction in PTSD remains to be investigated through brain imaging. Studies such as these may help to better understand relationships between self-eﬃcacy and the other three circuits (salience detection, fear learning, and contextual processing) that did not show changes in this study but may become targets in the context of speciﬁc tasks. Future work will continue to explore how enhancing perceptions of self-eﬃcacy may serve as an eﬀective therapeutic intervention to help patients with PTSD overcome persistent negative eﬀects of trauma by facilitating cognitive reframing in order to promote more adaptive problem solving and future thinking. Moreover, self-eﬃcacy interventions could also be investigated as a potential preventive tool utilized to prophylactically enhance resilience, a possibility that could be particularly relevant for military personnel prior to warzone deployments. Thus, those with PTSD in the NSE condition may be exhibiting greater disturbance in the balance of brain networks. Although additional research is needed to determine the effect of self-eﬃcacy on neural circuitry implicated in PTSD, these ﬁndings suggest that a high self-eﬃcacy intervention could possibly target emotional regulation and executive function circuitry and have a mitigating eﬀect on speciﬁc neural changes associated with this disorder. Interestingly, these ﬁndings in the ER/EF circuit converge with considerable research on self-regulation and emotion regulation showing the importance of prefrontal top-down executive function processes in response to stress (e.g. Ochsner et al., 2004; Ochsner et al., 2012). Therefore, strategies aimed at increasing coping ability through the modiﬁcation of self-appraisals, such as perceptions of coping self-eﬃcacy, may be targeting the prefrontal cortex.  that  While signiﬁcant progress in the understanding and treatment of PTSD has been made over the past several decades, current therapeutic options are not fully eﬀective, and there remains limited evidence on the ability of these treatments to target speciﬁc neural circuits implicated in PTSD (e.g. Malejko et al., 2017). The ﬁndings in this study suggest increasing self-eﬃcacy through the recall of autobiographical memories may serve as a non-pharmacological, non-invasive cognitive strategy for engaging neural targets that might aid in the treatment of PTSD. Limitations of this study include a relatively small sample size, and a study population speciﬁcally focused on male combat veterans. Additionally, while this study found potential neural diﬀerences associated with a self-eﬃcacy induction, the current work is unable to establish whether this leads to a reduction in PTSD symptoms. This study was also comprised entirely of individuals with PTSD. Additional research is needed to clarify whether these ﬁndings are speciﬁc to PTSD or would also be observed in healthy controls. Furthermore, the neural circuits in this study were guided by the neurobiological model characterized by Shalev et al. (2017). Future work would beneﬁt from examining whether increasing self-eﬃcacy inﬂuences other neural circuits and structures linked with PTSD, such as reward circuitry (e.g. Elman et al., 2009). Moreover, although a self-report measure of selfeﬃcacy was completed prior to the induction to show that levels of selfeﬃcacy did not diﬀer at baseline, a measure of self-eﬃcacy was not included post-induction. Follow up research is warranted to assess  R.F. Titcombe-Parekh et al. Fossati  GH Pitie Salpˆetriere, Service de Psychiatrie d’Adultes & CNRS USR 3246, AP-HP, CR-ICM, Universite Pierre & Marie Paris-VI, 47-83 bd de l’Hˆopital, Pavillon Pinel La Force, 75013 Paris, France  Received 23 May 2012; received in revised form 14 July 2012; accepted 18 July 2012  KEYWORDS Emotions; Processing; Imaging; Brain; Depression; Cognition  Abstract Different models of emotion highlight the role of strategic brain regions in emotion identiﬁcation, response and regulation. Cortical, subcortical and limbic structures constitute the emotional brain. In this short review, we focus on the function of the amygdala and medial prefrontal cortex. Both regions have reciprocal connections and are densely connected with cortical and subcortical structures. Beyond its classical role in fear processing, the amygdala is considered as a region that detects salient and personally relevant stimuli in cooperation with ventral and dorsal medial prefrontal cortex. Amygdala and medial prefrontal cortex are also engaged in the processing of socially relevant stimuli. Our review emphasized the overlap between the emotional and the social brain. Adopting a socio-affective neuroscience perspective is a promising perspective to identify new pathophysiological pathways in the study of emotion and mental disorders, especially major depressive disorder. & 2012 Elsevier B.V. and ECNP. All rights reserved.  1.  Introduction  Emotions are deﬁned as episodic and synchronized changes in the organism reﬂecting the quick identiﬁcation of salient stimuli in the environment and the production of adaptive behavioral and physiological responses. Although transient, emotional episodes are critical to survival and have strong and persistent inﬂuence on cognitive processes such as perception, attention, memory and decision-making (Dolan, 2002). Several components are usually considered in the study of emotion including physiological arousal, behavioral and motor expression, cognitive appraisal and subjective experience. At three models proposed in the  least  E-mail address: philippe.fossati@psl.aphp.fr  neuroscience of emotion mechanisms conceptualize the relationships between these different components: (1) basic emotion model; (2) dimensional feeling model; and (3) component process model (see Table 1; Scherer, 1984).  It is beyond the scope of this review to discuss each model but they all highlight the role of strategic brain regions for emotion perception, response and regulation. The so-called ‘emotional brain’ is composed of corticolimbic structures, such as medial and lateral prefrontal cortex, anterior cingulate, subcortical structures including basal ganglia, amygdala and hippocampus (Phillips et al., 2003). We propose here to review the role of the amydgala and medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC) in emotion processing. Because of their putative role in the pathophysiology of emotional disorders, such as anxiety or mood disorders, we decided to focus only on these regions.  0924-977X/$ - see front matter & 2012 Elsevier B.V. and ECNP. All rights reserved. http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.euroneuro.2012.07.008  S488  P. Fossati  Table 1 et al., 2008; Scherer, 1984).  Different models of emotion (see Grandjean  Basic emotion model  Dimensional feeling model  Component process model  This model distinguishes basic emotion from complex emotion. Basic emotion (i.e. fear, disgust, sadness, joy, surprise, anger) responses are provoked by speciﬁc events and are associated with speciﬁc physiological activation, facial expression and action tendencies. Basic emotions involve speciﬁc neural structures. According to this model fear is associated with a ‘circuit of fear’ with the amygdala as a core region of this circuit.  Emotions are here considered as verbal report of subjective feeling along several dimensions (valence, arousal). Emotion can be classiﬁed on different axes (positive– negative; approach– withdrawal). Within this model the prefrontal cortex especially the ventromedial prefrontal plays a major role in emotional processing as a hub for deﬁning affective meaning (Roy et al., 2012)  In this model, emotions are conceptualized as episodic changes in different subsystems (cognition, facial expression, physiological responses, subjective feeling) determined by salient stimuli pertinent for the survival of the organism. Changes are transient and synchronized and allow for ﬂexible adaptation to the environment. Appraisal, the process of evaluating the salience and importance of stimuli, is a central component of this model.  2. Methods  We conducted a qualitative review of studies on emotion processing with a special emphasis on neuroimaging studies. Studies on brain activation using fMRI were identiﬁed by a systematic search in Medline for English language manuscripts. The search query consisted of the MeSH terms: ‘FMRI and ‘Amygdala AND Fear detection’; ‘Amygdala AND Self relevance’; ‘Medial prefrontal Cortex AND Self Processing’; ‘Amygdala AND social cognition’.  3. Results  3.1. The amygdala: a threat detector?  Animal studies have made an important contribution to understanding of the anatomical and functional architecture of the amygdala. The primate amygdala is a nuclear complex composed of more than 10 nuclei, situated in the anterior part of the medial temporal lobe (LeDoux, 2007). In the primate, the basolateral nucleus receives projections from the thalamus and all sensory cortices and is connected to the central nucleus, the amygdaloid  the output  region of  complex. The amygdala has highly speciﬁc reciprocal connections with the prefrontal cortex. Among the prefrontal cortex, posterior orbito-frontal cortex and the ventral part of the anterior cingulate (i.e. Brodman area 25) show the strongest connections with the amygdala (Ghashghaei et al., 2007).  The amygdala sends widespread projections to subcortical and cortical areas such as basal fore-brain, striatum, nucleus accumbens, hippocampus, and sensory cortices (Amunts et al., 2005). The functional consequences of these projections and reciprocal connections remain to be fully understood.  However, special attention has been paid to the role of the amygdala in fear conditioning and threat detection. Fear conditioning is a form of emotional learning that describes how a neutral stimulus may become aversive and may elicit defensive behaviors (Phelps and LeDoux, 2005). In this type of experiment the subject or the animal is exposed to an emotional neutral stimuli (CS) such as a visual stimuli or a tone, paired with an aversive unconditioned stimuli (UCS; i.e. electric shock). An association is formed between the CS and US, and later presentation of the CS alone induces behavioral defense responses and associated autonomic and endocrine changes. Both animal and human brain imaging studies have demonstrated the role of the amygdala in fear conditioning (B¨uchel and Dolan, 2000; Phelps and LeDoux, 2005). Consistent with its role in fear acquisition, selective lesions of the amygdala impaired fear processing (see patient SM; Feinstein et al., 2011). Patients with amygdala damage have reduced experience of fear, a fact to be related to abnormal response to fear signals in patients with anxiety disorders. Likewise, patients with amygdala lesions showed reduced response to a fearful face. A recent meta-analysis (Fusar-Poli et al., 2009) of brain imaging studies revealed that the processing of human faces activates several brain areas including visual cortex, limbic areas, parieto-temporal cortex, prefrontal areas, putamen, cerebellum and amygdala. The amygdala was mainly but not speciﬁcally associated with the processing of fearful faces (see also Adolphs, 2008).  The contribution of the amygdala to fear processing has led many authors to conclude that the amygdala may be speciﬁcally devoted to the processing of fear-related stimuli (Ohman and Mineka, 2001). From an evolutionary perspective, the amygdala would constitute a modular system (a fear module) shaped by evolution to quickly and automatically respond to fearful or threatening stimuli. Such a ‘threat detector’ hypothesis would be consistent with basic emotion models suggesting that primary basic emotions are associated with unique physiological and behavioral responses and involve speciﬁc brain regions (Ekman, 1992).  3.2. Amygdala: from fear processing to detection of self-relevance  Brain imaging studies have challenged the ‘amygdala as a threat detector’ hypothesis. Several fMRI studies have shown that fear is not the only negative emotion that activates the amygdala. Anger and sadness faces were also shown to evoke amygdala responses (Blair et al., 1999; Fusar-Poli et al., 2009; Whalen et al., 2001). Moreover several studies suggest that positive emotional stimuli (i.e. happy face) activate the  Neural correlates of emotion processing: From emotional to social brain  S489  amygdala. One meta-analysis indicates that the effect-size of activation of the amygdala is even greater for positive stimuli than negative stimuli (Sergerie et al., 2008). Overall these results emphasize the need to deﬁne more precisely the computational role of the amygdala. Some tenants of the dimensional model of emotion argued that arousal and intensity are the main features of stimuli driving amygdala activation (Russell, 2003). As negative stimuli are usually more arousing and intense than positive stimuli this could explain the apparent bias for fearful faces in amygdala activation. Consistent with this interpretation Costafreda et al. (2008) found in their meta-analysis on the role of the amydala in emotion processing, that humour activated the amygdala more than happiness. As both stimuli have the same valence, the authors suggested that the arousal explained their results. Finally highly arousing stimuli such as sexual stimuli strongly activate the amygdala.  With the component process model, Sander et al. (2003) proposed that the amygdala implements evaluative processes related to the self-relevance of salient stimuli. According to this framework ‘the speciﬁcity and differentiation of emotion mostly relies upon the cognitive evaluation of the meaning and the consequences of a relevant external event within a speciﬁc context and relationship to one’s own goals’ (Sander et al., 2003). Self-relevance relates here to goals, needs, wellbeing and concerns. This could explain why amygdala response is preferential for some stimuli rather than others in speciﬁc contexts depending on the subject’s motivation. For instance response to food stimuli in the amygdala would increase if participants are hungry (Morris and Dolan, 2001). The selfrelevance model is also supported by the reciprocal connections between the amygdala and the orbital lateral and medial prefrontal cortex, regions implicated in the processing of value of stimuli (Miller and Cohen, 2001). The notion of relevance also helps to interpret individual differences in amygdala reactivity. Mood, personality trait, gender as well as genotype may modulate amygdala activity. Hariri et al. (2002) have shown that genes may inﬂuence the amygdala response to emotional negative faces. By studying a polymorphism of the serotonin– transporter-linked promoter region (5-HTTLPR), they showed that individuals carrying at least one S allele displayed greater amygdala reactivity to emotional stimuli than individuals homozygous for the L allele. Using a self-referential task where people were judging if emotional positive or negative pictures are self-related (e.g. pictures connected to personal interests, relative or memories), Lemogne et al. (2011b) showed that cognitive, environmental and genetic factors interact to modulate the amygdala response. The amygdala activation during self-referential processing was negatively correlated with selfreported life-stress in short allele carriers and positively in individuals homozygous for the long allele, whereas an opposite pattern was observed during emotion labeling. These results conﬁrm that the inﬂuence of the 5-HTTLPR polymorphism on amygdala reactivity is at least partially under cognitive control.  3.3. Amygdala, medial prefrontal cortex and social cognition  The self-relevance framework may also predict amygdala response to speciﬁc categories of stimuli. Social stimuli and social events are particularly relevant and emotional  disorders, especially major depressive disorders, are clearly precipitated by major social life-events (Kendler et al., 2003). Recently, studies of the human mind and brain have begun to explore the biological basis of our social abilities (Adolphs, 1999). Cortico-limbic regions that process emotional stimuli are involved in processing social stimuli. Indeed our emotional brain is a social brain.  The amygdala is sensitive to social signal such as faces, gaze direction, intention, and trustworthiness (Adolphs, 2010). Likewise, patients with amygdala lesions showed not only abnormal fear response but also impaired social behaviors. Amygdala lesions are associated with increased social approach and difﬁculties in monitoring interpersonal distance (Kennedy et al., 2009). These abnormal social behaviors bear some resemblance to behaviors observed with experimentally induced Kl¨uver-Bucy syndrome in primates (Mason et al., 2006). We can also speculate that impaired processing of interpersonal distance in patients with autistic disorders or social phobia may reﬂect an exaggerated response of the amygdala to social signals.  One brain region is particularly devoted to the processing of emotional and social stimuli, namely the medial prefrontal cortex. The medial prefrontal is composed of a ventral (VMPFC) and a dorsal part (DMPFC). Ventromedial areas of the prefrontal cortex comprise the medial orbital frontal cortex, the MPCC and the ventral and rostral anterior cingulate. They are densely connected with the amygdala and subcortical structures (ventral striatum). There are also connections between the VMPFC, and the dorsal anterior cingulate, the DMPFC, the dorsal lateral prefrontal cortex and the ventrolateral prefrontal cortex. These connections links medial regions implicated in emotion processing and lateral and dorsal prefrontal regions implicated in executive functions (Phillips et al., 2003).  Work by our group has emphasized the role of the VMPFC and DMPFC in self-referential processing and self-representation (Fossati et al., 2003, 2004; Lemogne et al., 2011a). The VMPFC cortex is associated with more automatic processing of self-relevant stimuli, whereas the DMPFC engaged more cognitive resources and introspective processes (i.e. self-reﬂection; Schmitz and Johnson, 2007).  The activation of medial prefrontal regions may also result from cognitive processes that are not self-speciﬁc. For instance, the dorsal part of MPFC is involved in tasks related to ‘theory of mind’ or ‘mentalizing’ which refers to the abilities to infer mental states of others (Adolphs, 2009). The ventral and dorsal MPFC are core components of the Default Mode Network (DMN) a network identiﬁed from resting state studies and from cognitively simple baseline tasks compared to more demanding experimental tasks. The DMN encompasses several cortical areas including the MPFC, precuneus, anterior cingulate cortices and posterior cingulated. Recently using an innovative design with a motor imitation paradigm, we observed that social interaction induces increased deactivation of the DMN, consistent with a role of medial prefrontal regions of the brain in the processing of social stimuli (Guionnet et al., in press).  Somerville et al. (2006) investigated human anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) involvement during a task where subjects make social judgment and receive ﬁctitious positive or negative feedback consistent or inconsistent with their expectations. The results demonstrated that the  S490  P. Fossati  ventral ACC was differentially responsive to social feedback. In a post hoc analysis, they additionally indicated that self-esteem modulates the ventromedial prefrontal cortex response to social feedback (Somerville et al., 2010). Using a similar paradigm in young people with major depression, Davey et al. (2011) found an increased amygdala activation in young people with major depression in response to social disapproval. MDD patients experienced heightened sensitivity to positive social signal indicating a non-speciﬁc arousal to social stimuli that were misinterpreted as aversive.  4. Discussion  We have brieﬂy reviewed the role of the amygdala and medial prefrontal cortex in emotion processing. Beyond the classical contribution of the amygdala to fear processing, our review suggests a more general role for this structure. The amygdala contributes to the cognitive appraisal of salient stimuli and the detection of personally relevant stimuli. Although the amygdala is a key player, the strong and reciprocal connections between this structure and cortical and subcortical regions call for the integration of a larger brain network in the detection of self-relevance and in processing the value of stimuli. Among these regions we have discussed the role of the medial prefrontal cortex in self-referential processing and social interaction. It is beyond the scope of this review to consider other regions such as the hippocampus or lateral prefrontal cortex. Due to its role in spatial cognition and autobiographical memory, the hippocampus may play a role in the contextualization of emotion. Lateral prefrontal cortex functions are related to cognitive control of emotion (Ochsner and Gross, 2005). Dorsolateral prefrontal and ventrolateral cortex by deﬁning priorities according to the goal of the subjects may control the responses of medial prefrontal regions and the amygdala. Dysfunctions of these control processes contribute to rumination in major depression, a symptom associated with increased self-focus and abnormal self-relevance of internal stimuli.  We have also emphasized the role of the medial prefrontal cortex in self-processing. The role of the medial prefrontal cortex is not limited to self-referential processing and many authors have identiﬁed the human ventromedial prefrontal cortex as a key region for several functions: autobiographical memory, fear extinction, economic valuation (Roy et al., 2012).  Finally, we did not discuss the role of the mirror neuron system (MNS) in social cognition and the interaction between the MNS, medial prefrontal cortex and amygdala. There is a common distinction in the literature between physical and evaluative aspects of the self. MNS and CMS are responsible, at different cognitive levels, for self-other mapping of physical actions and mental states, respectively. The connections between these two networks facilitate integration of information necessary for maintaining self– other representations across multiple domains (Uddin et al., 2007) in relation to emotion processing.  5. Conclusion  Social psychologists have long emphasized that emotion and cognitive processes are socially regulated. The overlap  between brain regions involved in emotion processing and in processing social stimuli underlines the need to adopt a socio-affective neuroscience perspective in the study of emotion. Applying this perspective in psychiatry is a promising and innovative development having the power to deﬁne new pathophysiological pathways and to yield functional biomarkers of mental disorders. In patients, emotion recognition impairments were found to be paralleled by cerebral dysfunctions in the affective division of the anterior cingulate cortex, the bilateral dorsomedial prefrontal cortex, the right superior temporal gyrus and the right fusiform gyrus. While the patients' responses to emotional faces were characterized predominantly by hypoactivations, the neutral faces elicited hyperactivations mainly in the frontal and cingulate areas, and the basal ganglia, along with misattribution errors. The decreased activation in the fusiform face area during responses to both emotional and neutral stimuli may be indicative of general face processing deﬁcits. Similar although less pronounced deﬁcits have been observed in subjects at high risk of psychosis as well as in patients with early onset. In adult schizophrenia, the evidence of an imbalanced cerebral network appears early in the course of the illness, with the dysfunctions, as indicated by correlations here, becoming more pronounced in patients with longer illness duration.  © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.  1. Introduction  In schizophrenia, a range of abnormalities have been detected in the regions associated with face recognition and emotion processing. The reduction of gray matter volume in the superior temporal gyrus (coding facial expressions (Haxby et al., 2002)) has been shown to be associated with thought disorder (Barta et al., 1997; Shenton et al., 1992) and acoustic hallucinations (Barta et al., 1990; Gaser et al., 2004; Sumich et al., 2005). Structural MRI studies have demonstrated that the gray matter volume of the fusiform gyrus (coding facial identity (Haxby et al., 2002)) is reduced in ﬁrst  ⁎ Corresponding author. Department of Psychiatry and Psychotherapy, RWTH Aachen University, Pauwelsstr. 30, D-52074 Aachen, Germany. Tel.: +49 241 80 80368; fax: +49 241 80 82401.  E-mail address: uhabel@ukaachen.de (U. Habel).  0920-9964/$ – see front matter © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. doi:10.1016/j.schres.2010.06.009  episode (Lee et al., 2002) and chronic schizophrenia (Onitsuka et al., 2003). The deactivation of the fusiform gyrus is associated with impaired face processing in subjects at risk of psychosis (Seiferth et al., 2009), and in juvenile (Seiferth et al., 2008) and adult patients (Quintana et al., 2003).  Neuroimaging studies of schizophrenia have demonstrated abnormalities in the amygdala and the hippocampus (Gur et al., 2002; Habel et al., 2004; Hempel et al., 2003; Holt et al., 2006; Kosaka et al., 2002; Schneider et al., 1998) – regions important for identiﬁcation of the emotional signiﬁcance of stimuli – and in the prefrontal cortex (Habel et al., 2004; Hempel et al., 2003) responsible for executive functions (Phillips et al., 2003).  The varied nature of the assigned tasks and the lack of consistency in the deﬁnition of emotional processing might have contributed to some of the divergent results yielded by previous studies assessing the dysfunctions in schizophrenia  114  U. Habel et al. / Schizophrenia Research 122 (2010) 113–123  and their neural correlates. Most studies have used passive viewing and implicit emotion processing tasks, requiring, for instance, simple emotion discrimination (e.g. Blair et al., 1999; Morris et al., 1998; Sprengelmeyer et al., 1998). In comparison to explicit tasks, those tasks (termed “implicit”) seem to reﬂect a less conscious level of emotional processing and entail different neural networks. Moreover, explicit and implicit tasks are not comparable in terms of requirements and processing load.  In the present study, our aim was to investigate the behavioral and neuronal responses of adult patients with schizophrenia and control subjects during an explicit facial– emotional discrimination task designed to distinguish between deﬁcits related to sensitivity (ability to name an emotion) and speciﬁcity (ability to discriminate between different emotional expressions and neutral faces). Unlike most previous studies on emotion recognition, the present study allowed us to distinguish between different emotional valences. Also, investigating brain responses to neutral faces, we sought to disclose any changes in the areas associated with facial processing. The event-related design of the task enabled us to characterize stimulus-related brain activation.  On a behavioral level, we expected to demonstrate, on the basis of our previous results, that in patients speciﬁcity is more affected than sensitivity. We hypothesized that in patients with schizophrenia emotion recognition impairments are accompanied by dysfunctions in the limbic system, the frontal cortex and the anterior cingulate, as these are regions heavily involved in emotion processing (and have been found, by many previous studies, to be affected in patients with schizophrenia). In addition, we aimed to locate affected areas reﬂecting general dysfunctions in emotional discrimination, independent of the emotional valence, as well as emotion-speciﬁc dysfunctions. Speciﬁcally, our study sought to identify altered functionality in the fusiform face area, conﬁrming the impairment in face perception in patients with schizophrenia. Based on our previous results with early onset and prodromal patients, we anticipated that the response to neutral faces would be qualitatively different from the one to emotional faces.  2. Patients and methods  2.1. Participants  Seventeen patients with schizophrenia were recruited from the Departments of Psychiatry and Psychotherapy of the Universities of Aachen and Düsseldorf, Germany.  The diagnosis was ascertained by clinical psychologists according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM)-IV criteria using the German version of Structured Clinical Interview for DSM IV (Wittchen et al., 1996). Patients with any other comorbid psychiatric or neurological disorder were not included.  Twelve patients were medicated with atypical antipsychotics (four patients received risperidone, four olanzapine, two ziprasidone, one amisulpride, and one clozapine), two with typical antipsychotics (haloperidol) and two with a combination of both (chlorprothixene and olanzapine, or ﬂupentixole and amisulpride). One patient was unmedicated. Mean time since the ﬁrst clinical admission was 9.9 (±8.6) years (min/max: 1/30).  The control group comprised seventeen healthy subjects matched for age, gender and parental education (Table 1). All participants were right-handed (Oldﬁeld, 1971). The protocol was approved by the local ethics committee, and signed by all participants.  2.2. Stimuli  We applied a modiﬁed version of the Facial Emotions for Brain Activation (FEBA) test (Gur et al., 2002; Schneider et al., 2006). The stimuli were selected from a standardized stimulus set, and the detailed task construction is reported elsewhere (Gur et al., 2002). The stimuli were made of colour photographs of faces (48 male, 48 female) – balanced according to age, sex and ethnicity – showing happy, sad, angry, fearful expressions or no emotion. After 4 runs, each face was seen by each subject exactly 5 times (4 emotional expressions and a neutral face).  2.3. FMRI paradigm  The event-related fMRI paradigm involved four randomly presented runs, in which one of the chosen emotions (fear, happiness, anger or sadness) was the target emotion. Hence the target emotion varied from run to run. Participants were instructed to answer by pressing a button with their left (target emotion) or right (non-target emotion or neutral face) index ﬁnger. The response hand was not counterbalanced across subjects. During the comparison of emotional conditions, the motor reaction was automatically omitted and, therefore, can be neglected. Each run was composed of 120 faces (32 targets, 32 emotional non-targets, and 56 neutral non-targets). Every stimulus was presented for 2 s with an interstimulus interval of 1 s (blank screen).  2.4. MRI data acquisition  Imaging was performed on a 1.5 Tesla Sonata MRI scanner (Siemens medical system, Erlangen, Germany) by means of an 8-channel headcoil. For fMRI, T2*-weighted echoplanar images (EPI, single shot pulse sequence, TR=3 s, ﬂip angle 90°) were taken parallel to the anterior/posterior commissural plane (30 slices, FoV 200×200 mm2, matrix 64×64, slice thickness 3 mm, 0.3 mm gap, voxel size 3.125×3.125×3 mm3). The fMRI session for emotion discrimination included 143 image volumes. A high resolution structural T1-weighted image (voxel size 1×1×1 mm3, sagittal FOV 256×256 mm2, 160 slices, TR=2.2 s, TE=4 ms, ﬂip angle=15°) was also obtained.  2.5. Analysis of behavioral data  The behavioral data were analysed by using SPSS 15 (SPSS Inc, 2006). Error probability was predeﬁned at α=0.05 (two tailed). Emotion discrimination performance was assessed by sensitivity (true positives/(true positives+false negatives)), speciﬁcity (true negatives/(true negatives+false positives)), and reaction time (RT; for both hits and correct rejections) for each emotional condition. True positives include all correct responses to targets, whereas the true negatives are deﬁned as correctly classiﬁed non-targets. False positives are the total number of responses when a non-target face was rated as a target, whereas false negatives are the number of targets falsely  U. Habel et al. / Schizophrenia Research 122 (2010) 113–123  115  Table 1 Demographic, neuropsychological and clinical characterizations. In order to compare patients and controls with respect to their sensitivity and speciﬁcity, we performed some additional exploratory analyses: First, we calculated the relative frequencies of true positive answers (TP) across the four target emotions and, accordingly, the relative frequencies of false positive answers (FP). To assess the relative contribution of neutral non-targets to the false positive rate, we restricted the analysis to the neutral stimuli (FP_n). According to signal-detection theory, relative frequencies were z-transformed in order to apply pair-wise comparisons by using ttests. Zero-frequencies were replaced by z-transforming (0.1)/ N (instead of 0/N), where N is the number of neutral stimuli. Comparisons between groups were performed for TP, FP and FP_n. Repeated-measures ANOVAs with the within-subject factor ‘emotion’ (happy, sad, angry, and fearful) and the between-subject factor ‘group’ (patients, healthy controls) were performed. Post-hoc analyses of signiﬁcant effects were carried out by t-tests (Bonferroni corrected for multiple comparisons). Socio-demographical, neuropsychological and psychopathological data were compared by two-sample t-tests.  2.6. FMRI analysis  2.6.1. Image preprocessing  Images were processed by means of the Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM5) software (Wellcome Dept. of Cognitive Neurology, 2003). The ﬁrst three images of each time series were excluded to account for T1-stabilization-effects. All remaining images were slice-time corrected and realigned to the ﬁrst image. The mean EPI volume of each session was estimated and coregistered with T1-weighted anatomical three dimensional image of each subject (Ashburner and Friston, 1997). Normalization parameters were determined for the anatomical images, which where coregistered to a standard T1-template (SPM5 distribution; linear and non-linear transformations, 5th degree spline interpolation to 2×2×2 mm3 resolution). These parameters were then applied to the coregistered functional timeseries, which was smoothed with a Gaussian kernel of 10 mm full width at half maximum.  2.6.2. Statistical analysis  For fMRI, ﬁrst level models were deﬁned for each subject within the general linear model (GLM) framework of SPM5. For each event type delta functions of stimulus onset times were convolved with the canonical hemodynamic response function, which were used as regressors in the GLM. Contrast images were generated for each condition vs. baseline (blank screen) and were included in a repeated-measures ANOVA on the 2nd level. This mixed two factorial design consisted of the within-subject factor facial emotion (with ﬁve levels: happy, sad, angry, fearful or neutral faces) and the between-subjects factor group (with two levels: patients and healthy controls). The 2nd level random effect analyses were performed using tcontrasts on the mixed-design ANOVA. Signiﬁcance level was set to p=0.001, uncorrected.  In patients, hypoactivation pertaining to emotion processing (independent of the speciﬁc emotion quality) was probed by means of a conjunction analysis, which was about the commonality of the four contrasts comparing controls with patients for each of the emotional conditions. Each single group comparison was thresholded at an uncorrected p-value of 0.01. Inference of this commonality was based on the conjunction null hypothesis (Nichols et al., 2005).  3. Results  3.1. Behavioral performance in emotion discrimination  In the analysis of speciﬁcity, a main effect for the factor group emerged (F=10.674, df=1/26, p=0.003), indicating a lower speciﬁcity for patients as compared to controls, whereas no group differences were observed in sensitivity. No group×emotion interaction was detected in either analysis (Fig. 1). Furthermore, within-group comparisons between FP and FP_n revealed that the healthy controls did not differ signiﬁcantly with respect to FP and FP_n (t=1.492, df=14, p=0.1580), whereas patients did (t=2.4387, df=14, p=0.0287), indicating that patients tend to ascribe emotions to neutral stimuli more than healthy controls do. Next, we show that patients misinterpreted the neutral faces as being angry (t=2.8977, df=27, p=0.0037) or fearful  116  U. Habel et al. / Schizophrenia Research 122 (2010) 113–123  Fig. 1. Emotional discrimination performance (M±SE) – sensitivity (left) and speciﬁcity (right) – of healthy controls and patients with schizophrenia. There were signiﬁcant differences between the two groups in speciﬁcity, but none with regard to sensitivity.  (t=2.3000, df=28, p=0.0146) more frequently than healthy controls. Patients with stronger negative symptoms showed a stronger tendency to perceive neutral faces as emotional (r=0.58, p=0.0306). A negative correlation between speciﬁcity and the duration of illness was observed (r=−0.70, p=0.007) (Fig. 3). We also detected a positive correlation between the duration of illness and negative symptoms (r = 0.6019, p=0.0295).  Group differences were observed in RT for correct rejections (F = 5.85, df = 1/26, p b0.023). Patients revealed slower  responses when correctly rejecting non-targets (pb0.001) (see Fig. 2).  3.2. FMRI results  3.2.1. Response to happy faces  The patients, compared to the healthy subjects, showed less activation in the bilateral anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), the bilateral medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC), the right dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (DMPFC) and the left ventrolat Fig. 2. Reaction times (M±SE) for speciﬁcity and sensitivity in the emotional discrimination performance of healthy controls and patients with schizophrenia. The longer the duration of illness, the lower the patient’s ability to reject a non-target emotion.  eral prefrontal cortex (VLPFC). The right superior temporal gyrus (STG), the right middle temporal gyrus and the left insula were also recruited less strongly by the patients. The same applied to the left hippocampus, the left parahippocampal gyrus and the right thalamus. Reduced activation was seen also in the right fusiform gyrus and in the occipital areas (Table 2), whereas the bilateral cuneus demonstrated increased activation (Table 2).  3.2.2. Response to sad faces  In patients, hypoactivation was seen in the bilateral ACC, the left DMPFC and the left VLPFC. Hypoactivation also emerged in  the right STG, the right middle temporal gyrus, the right fusiform gyrus and the right insula. The right caudate, the right thalamus und the bilateral cuneus (BA 17) were recruited to a lesser degree (Table 3). On the other hand, increased activation was detected in the right precentral gyrus, the right DLPFC, the bilateral cuneus (BA 18), right precuneus and the right putamen (Table 3).  3.2.3. Response to fearful faces  Compared to the control subjects, patients showed less activation in the right DMPFC, the right anterior cingulate and the bilateral cuneus (BA17) (Table 4). Group difference independent of emotional valence  The conjunction analysis demonstrated that in response to all presented emotions, patients showed less involvement of the rostral ACC, bilateral DMPFC, the right middle temporal gyrus and the right fusiform gyrus. The bilateral cuneus (BA 17, BA 18) was also recruited less strongly (Table 7; Fig. 6). Hyperactivations were detected in the right precentral gyrus (extending to the right inferior frontal gyrus), the right precuneus and the left cuneus (BA 19) (Table 7; Fig. 6).  4. Discussion  4.1. Speciﬁcity dysfunctions in emotion discrimination  Through our explicit emotion discrimination task (specially designed for in-depth characterization of emotion recognition deﬁcits in schizophrenia), we found patients to be impaired in their ability to correctly reject a non-target  emotion. While the ability to identify the target emotion was unaffected, patients showed a tendency to perceive the target emotion where it was not present. The error analysis revealed the patients' tendency to assign a negative emotion (fear or anger) to a neutral face. In patients with stronger negative symptoms, this tendency was more pronounced.  Further behavioral results indicate that individuals at high familial risk of schizophrenia (Eack et al., 2010), and patients with chronic schizophrenia, tend to consistently misinterpret neutral faces as negative (Kohler et al., 2003). On a cerebral level, in response to neutral faces, patients showed more activation in the prefrontal areas and in the middle orbital gyrus extending to the subgenual anterior cingulate (Fig. 5), the left cuneus, the right precuneus, the right parietal lobule, and the bilateral putamen. The hyperactivity in the emotionrelated brain regions in response to non-emotional information might be a consequence of aberrant attribution of emotional meaning to neutral stimuli. This observation is in line with the clinical phenomenology of schizophrenia. Negative attribution, cognitive biases, delusions and ideas of reference are related to the development of paranoia. There were detectable associations between negative symptoms and these behavioral results, which may be explained by the fact that the core negative symptoms are often associated  120  U. (B) Activation in the middle orbital gyrus (x=0 y=36 z=−14) extending to the subgenual cingulate cortex (pb0.001, uncorrected). (C) Activation in the middle orbital gyrus (x=0 y=36 z=−14) extending to the subgenual cingulate cortex (pb0.01, uncorrected). Hyperactivation in areas closely related to cognitive functions may indicate compensatory or regulatory processes meant to counterbalance these inadequate emotional responses. Decreased activation in the fusiform face area and the right superior temporal gyrus during responses to neutral stimuli may, on the other hand, point to general face processing deﬁcits in schizophrenia (see Section 4.2).  Using the same emotion discrimination task, we found subjects clinically at risk of psychosis showing stronger activation (in response to neutral faces) in the inferior and superior frontal gyri and the cuneus (Seiferth et al., 2008), although no behavioral deﬁcits were detected. This is in consistence with the fact that cerebral dysfunctions appear to precede behavioral impairments. Furthermore, the present study found behavioral deﬁcits to be more pronounced in patients with longer illness duration, which indicates that while deﬁcits are already present at early stages, they seem to progress along a chronic illness course.  4.2. Valence-independent general cerebral dysfunctions  The emotion recognition impairment in patients is also characterized by reduced cerebral responses to emotional stimuli in the anterior cingulate, bilateral DMPFC, bilateral cuneus, and the temporal pole. The dysfunction in the affective division of the ACC (Bush et al., 2000) corresponds to a region attributed to person perception, mentalizing and self-knowledge (Amodio and Frith, 2006) as well as emotional functions.  U. Habel et al. / Schizophrenia Research 122 (2010) 113–123  121  Fig. 6. Main activation clusters (p b0.01, uncorrected) for the group contrast patients bcontrols in response to happy, sad, angry, and fearful expressions (conjunction analysis). (A) Glass brain image of the conjunction analysis. (B) Deactivation in patients in the affective division of the ACC (x=6 y=36 z =22), the DMPFC (x=2 y =32 z=34) and the cuneus (x=−2 y=102 z =−4). (C) Deactivation in patients in the fusiform gyrus (x=42 y=−48 z =−16).  This is also supported by the meta-analysis of Phan et al. (2002) in which prefrontal activation in response to different emotions and mood induction procedures has been found within the ventral–rostral (BA 9 and 10) area of the prefrontal cortex extending into the affective subdivision of the ACC (BA 24, 32, 33). The authors suggest that prefrontal activation may reﬂect the cognitive evaluative aspects (attention, awareness, and appraisal) characteristic of all emotions. The ACC, among other functions, was found to be typically involved during emotional tasks with cognitive demand. This also applies to our emotional categorization task. DMPFC is also associated with mentalizing (Lieberman, 2005). It demonstrates that in schizophrenia, the impairment of emotion recognition abilities might underlie deﬁcits in the social cognitive processes.  The right fusiform face area, which is highly specialized in identifying human faces (Tsao and Livingstone, 2008), was recruited less strongly by patients (compared to controls) in response to emotional faces. Impaired functions of the fusiform face area (Marwick and Hall, 2008) suggest that basic encoding deﬁcits may also underlie the impairment in emotion classiﬁcation abilities in patients with schizophrenia.  Regardless of the valence of the emotional stimuli, stronger activation was observed in patients in the precentral area, the right inferior frontal gyrus, the right precuneus and in the left cuneus. Notably, juvenile patients with schizophrenia showed similar hyperactivation during performance of the same task in response to all facial expressions except sadness (Seiferth et al., 2009). Hence, the deﬁcit seems to be quite stable and present  early in the illness course. The hyperactivation of those regions (especially the inferior frontal gyrus and the precuneus) is likely to be a result of compensatory processes triggered to counterbalance the deﬁcit in emotion recognition and face processing. Alternatively, this activation in cognition-related areas (the precentral area, the inferior frontal gyrus, and the precuneus) may indicate a greater cognitive effort in patients to perform the task.  4.3. Emotion-speciﬁc dysfunctions  Here, patients demonstrated hypoactivation in the VLPFC (in response to sad, happy and angry faces), in the insula (sad and happy faces) and in the thalamus (in response to happy and sad faces). Reduced activation was also observed in the hippocampus (in response to happy faces) and in the caudate (in response to sad faces). Also, the STG (in response to happy, sad and angry faces) and the parahippocampal gyrus (in response to happy and angry faces) were less strongly recruited.  These results further indicate valence modulated dysfunctions (in the patients' perception of social/emotional information), which are superimposed onto general dysfunctions. They also point to speciﬁc dysfunctions in patients while attending to a certain target emotion during the task. Given that most of these regions are speciﬁcally associated with emotion processing, the results of this study once again support the notion that these deﬁcits cannot be solely attributed to cognitive problems.  122  U. Habel et al. / Schizophrenia Research 122 (2010) 113–123  4.4. Limitations and conclusions  Our sample was heterogeneous with respect to gender, age of illness onset, chronicity, and medication. We were also unable to quantify potential medication effects, since most patients received second generation antipsychotics, and potential transformations to chlorpromazine equivalents are still not handled consistently in the literature. However, our ﬁndings are in line with results from preceding studies including juvenile patients (Seiferth et al., 2009) and subjects clinically at risk of psychosis (Seiferth et al., 2008) as well as studies investigating unmedicated patients (Paradiso et al., 2003). The illness speciﬁcity of these deﬁcits remains to be determined.  Dysfunctions in the neural circuits involved in face and emotion processing underlie the reduced speciﬁcity in emotion recognition, demonstrating that perceptual processing may already be affected. We conclude that patients tend to misread a neutral face as angry or fearful, indicating increased neural activation in emotion-related areas in response to neutral faces as well as reduced activation in response to emotional faces in areas related to emotion and face processing representing facets of social cognitive processes. Hogrefe, Göttingen.  Neural correlates of social and nonsocial emotions: An fMRI study  Jennifer C. Britton,a,* K. Luan Phan,b Stephan F. Taylor,c Robert C. Welsh,d Kent C. Berridge,e and I. Liberzon c  www.elsevier.com/locate/ynimg  NeuroImage 31 (2006) 397 – 409  aNeuroscience Program, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA bPsychiatry Department, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL 60637, USA cPsychiatry Department, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA dRadiology Department, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA ePsychology Department, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, USA  Received 3 May 2005; revised 2 November 2005; accepted 14 November 2005 Available online 18 January 2006  Common theories of emotion emphasize valence and arousal dimensions or alternatively, specific emotions, and the search for the underlying neurocircuitry is underway. However, it is likely that other important dimensions for emotional neurocircuitry exist, and one of them is sociality. A social dimension may code whether emotions are addressing an individual’s biological/visceral need versus more remote social goals involving semantic meaning or intentionality. Thus, for practical purposes, social emotions may be distinguished from nonsocial emotions based in part on the presence of human forms. In the current fMRI study, we aimed to compare regional coding of the sociality dimension of emotion (nonsocial versus social) versus the valence dimension of emotion (positive versus negative). Using a novel fMRI paradigm, film and picture stimuli were combined to induce and maintain four emotions varying along social and valence dimensions. Nonsocial emotions of positively valenced appetite and negatively valenced disgust and social emotions of positively valenced joy/ amusement and negatively valenced sadness were studied. All conditions activated the thalamus. Appetite and disgust activated posterior insula and visual cortex, whereas joy/amusement and sadness activated extended amygdala, superior temporal gyrus, hippocampus, and posterior cingulate. Activations within the anterior cingulate, nucleus accumbens, orbitofrontal cortex, and amygdala were modulated by both social and valence dimensions. Overall, these findings highlight that sociality has a key role in processing emotional valence, which may have implications for patient populations with social and emotional deficits.
