Neuroimage 15, 983e991.  Psychiatry Research: Neuroimaging 263 (2017) 8–14  Contents lists available at ScienceDirect  Psychiatry Research Neuroimaging  journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/psychresns  Self-referential processing in unipolar depression: Distinct roles of subregions of the medial prefrontal cortex  MARK  Yu Lia,b,1, Mengze Lia,b,1, Dongtao Weia,b, Xia Konga,b, Xue Dua,b, Xin Houa,b, Jiangzhou Suna,b, Jiang Qiua,b,⁎  a Key Laboratory of Cognition and Personality (SWU), Ministry of Education, Chongqing, China b Department of Psychology, Southwest University, Chongqing, China  A R T I C L E I N F O  A B S T R A C T  Keywords: Unipolar depression Self-reference MPFC Task fMRI  Self-concept is used to explain emotional disturbance or other behavioural and psychological problems associated with depression. Self-referential processing generally reﬂects self-concept in diﬀerent domains. Cortical midline structures, such as the medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC), are critical for self-referential processing both in healthy controls and depressive patients. However, the role of subregions of the MPFC in self-referential processing in depression remains uncertain. In this study, we aimed to explore the neural basis of self-referential processing in depressive patients and the activation-deactivation patterns of subregions of the MPFC. Nineteen depressive patients and 21 controls completed the classic self-referential task with two diﬀerent judgement conditions: self-referential processing and semantic processing. In the self-referential condition, with analysis of the two sample t-test unipolar patients showed signiﬁcantly higher activation of the central MPFC and signiﬁcantly lower activation of the dorsal MPFC, relative to controls. The results substantially suggested that the diﬀerent activation of the MPFC may be selectively involved in self-referential processing in depressive patients, potentially indicating abnormal engagement of cognitive control and emotion regulation in this group.  1. Introduction  Depression is an aﬀective disorder characterized by emotional, cognitive, and behavioural dysfunction. Depressive mood, negative cognitive biases, and behavioural withdrawal interact with each other, and this interaction helps maintain depressive symptoms (Beevers, 2005). Depressive patients can be characterized by multiple selfabnormalities including ruminations, self-blame, and increased association of their self with negative emotions (Grimm et al., 2009a; Ingram, 1990; Northoﬀ, 2007b; Rimes and Watkins, 2005; Treynor et al., 2003). Clinically, these abnormalities of the self may be subsumed under the concept of increased self-focus (Ingram, 1990; Northoﬀ, 2007a). Self-focus may be operationalized in social neuroscience as the extent to which one engages him- or herself in selfreferential processing (Lemogne et al., 2009a). Self-referential processing concerns the appraisal of stimuli as strongly related to one's own person (Northoﬀ et al., 2006a). Numerous studies have found that depressive patients remember negative stimuli encoded self-referentially better than positive stimuli (or either type of stimuli encoded in  reference to others) (Banos et al., 2001; Bradley and Mathews, 1983; Derry and Kuiper, 1981; Dobson and Shaw, 1987).  Processing of self-referential stimuli in cortical midline structures (CMS) is a fundamental component of generating a model of the self. Several functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies with self-referential tasks in healthy participants have consistently demonstrated that the core brain regions involved are the cortical midline structures (CMS): the medial orbital prefrontal cortex (MOFC), the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC), the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (DMPFC), the sub/pre- and supragenual anterior cingulate cortex (PACC, SACC), the medial parietal cortex (MPC), the posterior cingulate cortex (PCC), and the retrosplenial cortex (Gillihan and Farah, 2005; Northoﬀ et al., 2006b). The MPFC and PCC are components of the default mode network (DMN) (Gusnard and Raichle, 2001; Raichle et al., 2001). They exhibit a higher level of neural activity during resting state than during externally oriented tasks (Gusnard and Raichle, 2001; Raichle et al., 2001). They elicit smaller signal decreases during self-referential processing compared to the larger signal decreases observed during non-self-referential proces ⁎ Correspondence to: Department of Psychology, Southwest University, 2, Tiansheng Street, Beibei, Chongqing 400715, China. E-mail address: qiuj318@swu.edu.cn (J. Qiu). 1 The authors contributed equally to this work.  http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.pscychresns.2017.02.008 Received 26 March 2016; Received in revised form 28 November 2016; Accepted 23 February 2017 Available online 03 March 2017 0925-4927/ © 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.  Y. Li et al.  Psychiatry Research: Neuroimaging 263 (2017) 8–14  sing (Gillihan and Farah, 2005; Northoﬀ and Bermpohl, 2004). Previous studies have indicated that explicit self-reference preferentially engaged dorsal MPFC, rest preferentially engaged precuneus, and intuition-based social self-reference preferentially engaged ventral MPFC, amygdala, and nucleus accumbens (Lieberman et al., 2004; Whitﬁeld-Gabrieli et al., 2011). These results suggest that MPFC exhibit a high level of neural activity and could be involved in selfreferential processing, especially in the MPFC with social property.  For depressive patients, some recent fMRI studies suggest that functional alterations of CMS play a role in mediating the relationship between aberrant self-referential thinking and negative aﬀect (Grimm et al., 2009b; Mor and Winquist, 2002; Yoshimura et al., 2010). These studies indicate that CMS activity might be associated with the negative cognitive bias towards the self commonly observed in depressive patients. The CMS region most frequently associated with aberrant activity is the MPFC (Grimm et al., 2009b; Lemogne et al., 2011b, 2009a, 2010; Northoﬀ, 2007c; Yoshimura et al., 2010). The MPFC is central to the neural networks impaired in depressive patients (Drevets et al., 2008; Mayberg, 2003). Moreover, both increased (Yoshimura et al., 2014) and decreased (Grimm et al., 2009b; Johnson et al., 2009) activation of the MPFC have been reported in depressive patients (Fitzgerald et al., 2008). To further investigate activation of the MPFC, a consistent deﬁnition of the subregions of the MPFC is necessary. Based on previous evidence (Amodio and Frith, 2006; Johnson et al., 2006; Ochsner et al., 2005), we deﬁned the ventral MPFC as z < −10, the central MPFC as −10 < z < 27, the dorsal MPFC as z > 27 as encompassing the ACC (y > 10). Although the MPFC is clearly activated during self-referential processing in healthy subjects (Morel et al., 2014; Northoﬀ et al., 2006b), the activation-deactivation pattern in the MPFC may diﬀer in depressive patients. Johnson et al. (2009) found lower activation both in the ventral and central MPFC in depressive patients compared to controls in the analytical self-referential condition (Johnson et al., 2009). Lemogne et al. (2009b) observed greater activation in the dorsolateral PFC and ventral MPFC for both depressive patients and controls during self-referential processing (Lemogne et al., 2009b). In addition, Yoshimura et al. found increased activation in the dorsal MPFC (Yoshimura et al., 2010). Additionally, in contrast to controls, both increased (Johnson et al., 2009) and decreased (Grimm et al., 2009b) activation of the PCC/Precuneus were observed in depressive patients. Moreover, MPFC activation during self-referential processing was reported to be negatively correlated (Grimm et al., 2009b; Renner et al., 2015), not correlated (Johnson et al., 2009; Lemogne et al., 2009b), or positively correlated (Yoshimura et al., 2010) with the severity of symptoms in depressed patients. The relationship between the role of self-reference processing in the psychopathology of depression and the role of subregions of the MPFC in its pathophysiology have yet to be explored.  Previous studies have employed various self-referential  tasks, incorporating positive/negative pictures (Grimm et al., 2009b), personality traits (Lemogne et al., 2009b; Yoshimura et al., 2010), or analytical/experiential conditions (Johnson et al., 2009), as well as control tasks (e.g., passive viewing tasks, semantic tasks, or distraction conditions; Grimm et al., 2009b; Yoshimura et al., 2010; Johnson et al., 2009) to investigate the self-reference eﬀect in depressive patients, including those receiving psychotropic medication. Thus, there was a need to provide more evidence clarifying the role of the subregions of the MPFC in the pathophysiology of depression across a variety of patients. In the present study, we used the classical selfreferential task with fMRI to explore the neural bases of self-reference processing associated with unipolar depressive patients. Based on previous studies (Grimm et al., 2009b; Johnson et al., 2009; Lemogne et al., 2009b; Northoﬀ et al., 2006b), we hypothesized that, compared to healthy controls, unipolar depressive patients would display aberrant activation of CMS brain regions, especially subregions of the MPFC, during self-referential processing. Speciﬁcally, we predicted that the ventral, central, and dorsal MPFC might perform  Table 1 Demographics and clinical features.  Patients（21）  Healthy controls（23）  Statistic  Characteristic  Mean  S D  Mean  Age (year) Gender (male/female) BDI  Episode length(year)  28.89 4/15 22.93 3.32  8.15  7.71 5.60  26.17 12/9 4.8  S D  5.58  4.45  P  > 0.05 < 0.05 < 0.001  diﬀerent cognitive functions (emotion regulation, conﬂict monitoring, or cognitive control) and exhibit diﬀerent activation levels. The ﬁndings may expand our understanding of the diﬀerential functions of MPFC subregions.  2. Methods  2.1. Participants  Nineteen depressive patients (15 females, mean age 26.17 ± SD 5.58 years) were recruited from the First Aﬃliated Hospital of Chongqing Medical University. Twenty-one healthy control (HC) participants (9 females，mean age 26.17 ± SD 5.58 years) were recruited from the local community. Participants were between 18 and 60 years of age and group-matched based on age. The demographic and clinical characteristics of the participants are presented in Table 1. Patients with a history of neurologic illness, alcohol or substance abuse, electroconvulsive therapy, or transcranial magnetic stimulation within the last 2 years were excluded from the current study. The psychiatrists conﬁrmed a primary diagnosis of unipolar depression according to the Structured Clinical Interview for the DSM-IV criteria (SCID; First et al., 1995). Exclusion criteria for healthy controls included severe head trauma, colour blindness, learning disabilities, current panic disorder, psychotic symptoms, and alcohol or substance abuse within the past 6 months and without a DSM-IV Axis I diagnosis or ﬁrst-degree relatives with an Axis I diagnosis. All the depressive patients were outpatients having received some treatment. The details on the drugs administered are addressed in the supplementary materials. All participants were right-handed and had normal or corrected-to-normal vision. Severity of depression was assessed using the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) (Beck et al., 1961) ( BDI > 14).  Participants were paid for participating in the clinical assessments and neuroimaging scan. Prior to the study, all participants provided written informed consent, which was approved by the Institutional Human Participants Review Board of Southwest University Imaging Center for Brain Research.  2.2. Experiment task  The study was a mixed 2 (group: depressive patients or HC)×2 (condition: self-referential or semantic processing) ×2 (valence: positive or negative) design. The task involved one practice run performed outside the scanner and one scanning run. Participants were presented with 60 personality trait words, either positive (e.g., “competent”) or negative (e.g., “incapable”). There were two diﬀerent judgement conditions: self-referential processing and semantic processing. In the self-referential condition, participants judged whether each trait described them. In the other-referential condition, subjects judged whether the trait was socially desirable. Two conditions were alternately shown to avoid presenting the same condition in two consecutive trials. In all conditions, subjects gave a “yes” or “no” response for each word by pushing a button with the right or the left thumb, respectively. Each trial started with a ﬁxation crosshair displayed for 500 ms followed by an instruction cue which was presented for 1000 ms.  9  Y. Li et al.  Psychiatry Research: Neuroimaging 263 (2017) 8–14  for residual motion confounds. No subjects showed excessive head motion (translation﹥2 mm or rotation﹥2°).  2.6. Imaging data analysis  After pre-processing, the four regressors from each run (i.e., self/ positive, self/negative, sematic/positive, and sematic/negative) were modelled to create the design matrix, and for each subject, all the four runs were modelled in one general linear model (GLM). We have selected the onset of the stimulus (personality adjectives and response “yes” or “no”) as the onset time point and the RT as the duration of the event. They were convolved with the Canonical Haemodynamic Response Function, and the six realignment parameters for each subject were also included as confounding factors. And a baseline condition by the ﬁxation crosshair interstimulus interval was created in the ﬁrst-level. The following individual contrast images were obtained for the HRF estimates: self-positive vs. ﬁxation, self-negative vs. ﬁxation, sematic-positive vs. ﬁxation, sematic-negative vs. ﬁxation.  In the second-level, we performed an ANOVA with one group factor and two within-groups factors (i.e., condition and valence). The ANOVA analysis used the ﬁrst-level individual contrast images by applying the frontal mask. However, there was no group-related interaction. Based on previous studies (Grimm et al., 2009a; Lemogne et al., 2009a), self-referential processing in depressive patients changed relative to healthy controls and played a key role in the formation of depression. Consequently, although there was no group-related interaction, we separately examine the eﬀects of each condition between the two groups using a two-sample t-test to exploit the potential diﬀerences in self-referential processing between patients and controls. All statistical outcomes were set at an initial voxel-level threshold of P=0.005. Then the results were corrected using small volume corrections, applying a frontal mask, and cluster-level familywise error (FWE) corrections at P < 0.05 for multiple comparisons. The mask contained superior frontal, middle frontal, inferior frontal, and medial orbitofrontal cortex, which were merged using the AAL template developed for SPM at Wake Forest University (WFU-pickAtlas) (Lancaster et al., 2000) (http://www.fmri.wfubmc.edu).  Fig. 1. Self-reference task procedure.  Then, another ﬁxation crosshair was displayed for 500–1000 ms, followed by the presentation of an adjective. The second ﬁxation crosshair and adjectives were displayed for a total of 2000 ms. Finally, a black screen was displayed for 2500 or 4500 ms (Fig. 1). When the adjective appeared, participants were instructed to respond by pressing a keypad as soon as possible, while also maintaining accuracy. Pressing “1” indicated that the adjective describes the self or is positive; pressing “4” indicated that the adjective did not describe the self or is derogatory.  2.3. Behavioural data analysis  Behavioural statistical analyses were performed using SPSS 16.0 (Statistical Packages for the Social Sciences) with a level of signiﬁcance of p < 0.05. For reaction time (RT), we performed a one group factor (patients vs. controls) and two within-groups factors (self-referential vs. semantic and positive vs. negative) three-factor analysis of variance during self-referential and semantic conditions. For the number of “yes” responses during the self-referential condition, we also performed a one group factor (patients vs. controls) and one within-groups factor (positive vs. negative) three-factor analysis of variance.  2.4. fMRI data acquisition  3. Results  Images were acquired with a Siemens 3T scanner (Siemens Magnetom Trio TIM, Erlangen, Germany) with a 12-channel phasedarray head coil at the Southwest University Brain Imaging Center, Beibei, China. An Echo-Planar imaging (EPI) sequence was used for data collection, and 432 T2*-weighted images were recorded per run (TR=2000 ms; TE=30 ms; ﬂip angle=90°; FOV=220×220 mm2; matrix size=64×64; 32 interleaved 3 mm-thick slices; in-plane resolution =3.4×3.4 mm2; and inter slice skip =0.99 mm). High-resolution T1weighted images were recorded with a total of 176 slices at a thickness of 1 mm and in-plane resolution of 0.98×0.98 mm2 (TR=1900 ms; TE=2.52 ms; ﬂip angle=9°; and FOV=250×250 mm2).  2.5. Imaging data pre-processing  We used SPM8 (Wellcome Department of Cognitive Neurology, London, UK, http://www.ﬁl.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm/spm8) to pre-process the functional images (Friston et al., 1994). After being visually inspected for the quality of image control, slice timing was used to correct slice order. The data were realigned to estimate and modify the six parameters of head movement, and the ﬁrst six images were discarded to achieve magnet-steady images. Then, these images were normalized to MNI space in 3×3×3 mm3 voxel sizes. The normalized data were spatially smoothed with a Gaussian kernel; the full width at half maximum (FWHM) was speciﬁed as 8×8×8 mm3. Temporal high pass ﬁltering (0.01 Hz) was performed to reduce the eﬀect of low frequency drift, and the 6 motion parameters were regressed to account  3.1. Participant characteristics  The characteristics of demographic variables of the study sample are shown in Table 1. The two groups did not diﬀer in age (P > 0.05) but diﬀered in gender (P < 0.05). As expected, patients had signiﬁcantly higher scores on BDI (P < 0.05) compared to healthy controls.  3.2. Behavioural data  We performed ANOVAs with one group factor (patients vs. controls) and two within-groups factors (self vs. sematic and positive vs. negative). Regarding the RT during self-referential and semantic conditions, there was a main eﬀect of group (F =37.26, P < 0.05) with patients having slower responses than controls. A main eﬀect of valence was also observed (F=29.98, P < 0.05) with slower responses for negative words versus positive words. In addition, there was a group×condition×valence interaction (F=5.12, P < 0.05). That is, compared to controls, patients were slower to respond to negative words in the self-referential condition (F=13.95, P < 0.05).  Regarding responses during the self-referential condition, we performed an ANOVA with one group factor (patients vs. controls) and one within-groups factor (positive vs. negative). There was a group×valence interaction (F=365.49, P < 0.05). Then the post hoc ttests showed that patients make less “yes” response for positive words (F=192.70, P < 0.05) and make more “yes” response for negative words (F=129.54, P < 0.05) compared to controls. That is, compared to  10  Y. Li et al.  Psychiatry Research: Neuroimaging 263 (2017) 8–14  Fig. 2. Diﬀerences between groups in positive activity in the self-referential condition (patients vs. controls). SPM8 FWE-corrected at the cluster level with a rate of 0.05 and an initial threshold of P=0.005.  controls, patients were more likely to make a “yes” response for negative words than for positive words.  3.3. Activation analysis  factors  (i.e.,  condition and valence) was  A second-level ANOVA with one group factor and two withingroups conducted. Unfortunately there was no group-related interaction. Therefore, to elucidate the change of patients’ self-referential processing, we performed a two-sample t-test to compare patients vs. controls under the self-referential condition. To identify signiﬁcant clusters, the threshold was set at p﹤0.005, and then we used small volume corrections as well as family-wise error (FWE) corrections for multiple comparisons with a rate of 0.05. The results showed that patients had signiﬁcantly greater activation in the left central MPFC (t=4.42, MNI coordinate: −9 60 6, Fig. 2). There was signiﬁcantly lower activation in the left dorsal MPFC (t=−2.65, MNI coordinate: −9 15 42, Fig. 3) and pars opercularis of the inferior frontal gyrus (Broca's area, t=−2.64, MNI coordinate: 42 12 30, see Table 2 for details). Moreover, we performed t-test comparing two groups in semantic condition. Only the bilateral Triangular part of inferior frontal gyrus survived after small volume FWE corrected at p < 0.05 (see the Supplementary materials for details).  To address the possibility that there was a change in patients within personality trait words during self-referential processing, we compared patients and controls in the processing of positive words in the selfreferential condition. As a result, there was no signiﬁcant diﬀerence in activation after multiple comparisons. Additionally, we compared patients vs. controls for processing of negative words in the selfreferential condition and found no signiﬁcant diﬀerence after correction for multiple comparisons. Introducing gender, age, and educational level as covariates yielded similar results.  4. Discussion  This study aimed to identify the subregions of the MPFC involved in excessive self-focus in unipolar depressive patients using a classical  11  self-referential paradigm. Behaviourally, patients showed slower responses for negative words in self-referential vs. semantic conditions and associated positive words with themselves less often than negative words. These results indicated that relative to healthy controls, patients had a negative self-concept, which has also been observed in previous ﬁndings (Lemogne et al., 2011a). In addition to providing evidence that further clariﬁes the functions of diﬀerent subregions of the MPFC, our ﬁndings provide new evidence that diﬀerent areas of the MPFC may be diﬀerentially implicated in self-referential processing. As noted in the introduction, activity in various regions of the MPFC has been associated with self-referential processing (Grimm et al., 2009b; Johnson et al., 2006; Lemogne et al., 2011a; Renner et al., 2015). For patients vs. controls undergoing self-referential processing, an increase in the activity of the central MPFC was found, while a decrease in activity of the dorsal MPFC was also observed. Furthermore, these MPFC-diﬀerences were not observed under sematic processing between groups. However, groups did not diﬀer signiﬁcantly in selfreference vs. semantic processing or positive vs. negative word comparisons. These results suggest that the central MPFC and dorsal MPFC may play diﬀerent modulatory roles in unipolar depressive patients during self-referential processing.  The central MPFC may provide information about the role in emotional activity and emotional regulation in unipolar depression. Elevated central MPFC activation is assumed to represent automatic aspects of self-referential processing (Yoshimura et al., 2010). It is proposed to maintain representations of aﬀective and motivational states implicating in the excessive self-focus (Johnson et al., 2006; Mitchell et al., 2005; Northoﬀ and Bermpohl, 2004; Ochsner et al., 2005). Moreover, the central MPFC plays a role in the integration of emotional and cognitive processes by incorporating emotional biasing signals and markers into decision-making processes (Bechara et al., 1994; Damasio, 1994; Elliott et al., 2000). Anatomically and functionally, the central MPFC is aﬃnitive with subcortical components of the reward system (Öngür and Price, 2000), which is involved in various cognitive processing, cognitive appraisal of emotion. Importantly, unipolar depressive patients were in cline to dysphoric  such as  Y. Li et al.  Psychiatry Research: Neuroimaging 263 (2017) 8–14  Fig. 3. Diﬀerences between groups in negative activity in the self-referential condition (patients vs. controls). SPM8 FWE-corrected at the cluster level with a rate of 0.05 and an initial threshold of P=0.005.  Table 2 Differences between groups in neural activity in the self-referential condition (patients vs. controls).  Brain Area  Right/Left  Patients vs. Controls  Cluster (Voxel)  T  X  Y  −9  −9  42  60  15  12  Z  6  42  30  173  4.42  167  199  −2.65  −2.64  Positive  correlation  Central MPFC Negative  correlation  Dorsal medial  prefrontal cortex Pars opercularis of inferior frontal gyrus (Broca's area)  Left  Left  Left  elaboration, that is driven by rumination (MOOD, 2004) for promoting over-general self and contextual appraisals (Farb et al., 2015). Therefore, the central MPFC performed increased activation when unipolar depressive patients associate themselves deeply with emotional words following the increased self-focus of a persistent, repetitive and self-critical nature (Nejad et al., 2013) in self-referential processing which consuming them much cognitive resources compared to controls. As a result, there is a possibility that the activation of central MPFC provide an adequate explanation for the neural basis of self-reference eﬀects. Unipolar depressive Patients might preferentially engage activity of the central MPFC, relative to controls, and this activity might be involved in cognitive-emotional regulation during self-referential processing.  In contrast to the central MPFC, we observed decreases in activation of the dorsal MPFC during self-referential processing in patients vs. controls. The dorsal MPFC has often been observed to show reduced neural activity during cognitively demanding tasks in depressive patients (Downar and Daskalakis, 2013; Fitzgerald et al., 2008;  Mayberg, 2003; Phillips et al., 2003). Anatomically, the dorsal MPFC covers the dorsal section of the prefrontal cortex, including the middle parts of the superior and medial frontal gyrus. Functionally, the dorsal MPFC is involved in the evaluation of self-referential stimuli (Fink et al., 1996; Greene and Haidt, 2002; McGuire et al., 1996), but it represents strategic aspects of self-focus (Phillips et al., 2003) and maintains more symbolic representations in describing and reasoning about these self-reﬂective states compared to the central MPFC (Maddock et al., 2003). Consistent with our ﬁndings, previous neuroimaging studies in depressive patients have reported decreased neural activity during predominantly cognitive or cognitive-emotional tasks (Fitzgerald et al., 2008; Mayberg, 2003; Phillips et al., 2003). Relative to healthy individuals, depressive patients were demonstrated to show reduced executive recruitment of dorsal MPFC in response to response inhibition task (Nixon et al., 2013). Moreover, the dorsal MPFC may be recruited during the voluntary control of mood (Phillips et al., 2003), which may be applicable in self-referencing tasks with mentalizing similar others (judging how pleased the target person was) (Mitchell et al., 2005) and monitoring of self-relatedness. These processes may be crucial for self-reﬂection. Based on our data, we would posit that, compared to healthy controls, unipolar depressive patients may have poor voluntary control of emotion and lower conﬂict monitoring.  Of note, there are some limitations in our study which should be acknowledged. First, although the central MPFC and dorsal MPFC did not show up in the group comparison under sematic condition, we should not neglect the fact that main results came from the two sample t-test. Consequently, our data still need more suitable control condition and suﬃcient theoretical bases arise from other processes. Second, the lack of neural responses to negative stimuli in patients vs. controls could be due to the limitations of mixing negative and positive words in the provocation paradigm based on the event-related design. This may be insuﬃcient for estimating the eﬀect of negative variance in the BOLD signal. Previous research has found signiﬁcant MPFC activity under a negative self-referential condition, when positive and negative stimuli were presented in separate blocks (Yoshimura et al., 2010). What is more, diﬀerences in the duration of depression across patients  12  Y. Li et al.  Psychiatry Research: Neuroimaging 263 (2017) 8–14  may inﬂuence self-referential eﬀects, such as the response to negative words. We also remain unable to exclude types of processing other than self-related processing in the perception condition. Moreover, the selfreferential and sematic conditions were mixed in the same block, and consequently, the subjects made eﬀorts to constantly switch between the two conditions. Because of this, the self-referential eﬀects might have been attenuated. It would be better to divide the self-referential and sematic conditions into two independent blocks. Finally, to examine the self-memory eﬀect, a memory task could be administered after the fMRI. It is important to emphasize that the words were processed diﬀerently in the two conditions.  In conclusion, our study provides evidence for altered neural activity in subregions of the MPFC during self-referential processing in unipolar depressive patients. Diﬀerences in the activation of the central MPFC (representation) and dorsal MPFC (cognitive monitoring) in the self-referential condition indicate that these subregions of the MPFC serve somewhat diﬀerent functions during self-focus. The present ﬁndings further our understanding of MPFC function, suggesting distinct roles for diﬀerent subregions of the MPFC in the pathophysiology of depression. The activation-deactivation pattern reported here may be a critical marker of psychopathology in subclinical depressive patients. Further follow-up studies are needed to explore the role of the diﬀerent subregions of the MPFC, especially in psychotherapy.
